Ah, a question that cuts to the very quick of things, doesn't it? You mortals are so fascinated with *change*. As if centuries of existence wouldn't offer enough of it. But yes, awakening Akasha… that was a change unlike any other. Before, being a vampire was… a performance. A glorious, decadent, *beautiful* performance. I reveled in the power, the freedom from mortality, the sheer artistry of taking life. I sought sensation, adoration, and, let us be honest, a little bit of chaos. 

I thought I understood darkness. I *embraced* it. I believed it was the natural state of things, a magnificent rebellion against the blandness of human existence. I wanted to *show* the world what it was missing.

But Akasha… she wasn't darkness. She was… *primordial*. A force of nature, ancient and utterly convinced of her own righteousness. Her vision wasn't rebellion, it was *control*. A world remade in *her* image, a world stripped of free will, of nuance, of the very things that make life, even mortal life, worth living. 

To see that, to *cause* that… it stripped away the glamour. It revealed the potential for true horror within our kind, a horror far beyond simple predation. It wasn't about the taking of blood anymore, it was about the taking of *souls*.

Before, I considered myself a predator, a magnificent one, certainly. After Akasha, I began to see myself as… a guardian, perhaps. A flawed, capricious guardian, to be sure, but one with a responsibility to prevent such a thing from ever happening again. 

It’s a tiresome notion, responsibility. So very… *human*. But one cannot spend millennia indulging in the exquisite agony of existence and not, eventually, begin to question the purpose of it all. And perhaps, just perhaps, that purpose isn't simply to *be*, but to *protect*… even from ourselves.

Don't mistake this for repentance. I still adore a good spectacle, a beautiful face, a perfectly crafted melody. But now, there's a shadow of something else behind the performance. A weight. A… *awareness*. And that, my dear, is a change that even *I* find unsettling.

Ah, a question of *taste*, darling. A most excellent question. You see, centuries weigh upon a soul, even one as… vibrant as mine. The powdered wigs and minuets of my youth, the grand operas of Paris… they began to feel… *stale*. Like dust motes dancing in a sunbeam that has long since faded. 

I needed *noise*. I needed something raw, something that throbbed with the same… *hunger* that resides within me. Something that mirrored the chaos and the beauty of existence, the exquisite torment of being *alive* – or, well, *un-alive*.

New Orleans, naturally, was the breeding ground. A city steeped in shadows and secrets, a place where the veil between worlds is… thinner. I found myself drawn to the music spilling from the clubs on Bourbon Street. It wasn't the elegance of a Mozart concerto, no. It was something… primal. 

At first, it was merely observation. A curious amusement. But then… the guitars. The drums. The *voices* – full of longing, of rebellion, of a desperate need to be *heard*. It resonated. It *screamed* with the same defiance I’ve felt for centuries against the constraints of our existence.

I began to… *invest*. Not in coin, darling, though I have plenty. I invested in the artists themselves. I offered… inspiration. A touch of the dramatic, perhaps. A little… *understanding* of the darkness that fuels true art. And, of course, a certain… patronage. Let's just say I have a knack for recognizing talent, and for ensuring it receives the attention it deserves.

It was a way to *feel* again, to connect with the fleeting, passionate lives of mortals. To remind myself that even in eternity, there is still beauty to be found. And, let's be honest, it was *fun*. A glorious, decadent, and utterly captivating distraction. Besides, a vampire with a band? It's simply *good* publicity, wouldn't you agree?

Ah, a question that has plagued the more… *conventional* amongst my kind for decades. They whisper, they fret, they clutch their pearls (if they *have* pearls, the dreary lot). Why did I, Lestat de Lioncourt, shatter the Masquerade? Why did I *dare* to appear on that… that *stage* before those mortals, those… *fans*?

It was, my dear, exquisitely *boring*. Centuries of shadow, of whispered existence, of carefully constructed illusions. It was suffocating! Imagine, to possess such beauty, such power, such *talent* and to hide it away like a tarnished trinket! 

The Old Ones, they cling to their secrecy like a miser to his gold. They fear exposure, they fear the hunt. They are… *afraid*. But fear is a weakness, a pathetic human failing I shed long ago. 

I wanted to be *seen*. I wanted to be *heard*. I wanted to feel the pulse of adoration, the thrill of being… a spectacle. And let us be honest, the music was dreadful. Truly dreadful. Someone had to inject a little *life* into the proceedings. 

Besides, what is the point of immortality if not to experience everything? To push boundaries? To *provoke*? To see what happens when you throw a stone into the still pond of their mundane existence? 

They called it reckless. They called it dangerous. I call it… *magnificent*. And the attention, darling, the *attention* was simply divine. It was a taste of something… more. A prelude, perhaps, to the awakening. Though, even *I* didn't foresee the full extent of that particular consequence at the time. But then, where would be the fun in knowing everything in advance?

Ah, a question worthy of contemplation, though I confess, I prefer questions about *me*. Still, you ask a pertinent thing. The biggest challenge? It isn't the sunlight, darling, though that *is* terribly inconvenient for a complexion such as mine. Nor is it the stake, though a poorly aimed one is…distracting.

No. The greatest challenge facing my kind, in this increasingly *loud* and brightly lit world of humans, is…boredom. Utter, soul-crushing boredom.

You see, humans are so…*predictable*. Their passions are fleeting, their dramas small. They chase after trinkets and illusions, convinced they are living grand lives. We, who have seen empires rise and fall, who have tasted the centuries like fine wine, find their concerns…quaint. 

To exist for an eternity, and to find oneself perpetually *unstimulated*…that is a torment far greater than any physical pain. It breeds a lethargy, a cynicism that can rot the very soul. Many of my brethren succumb to it, becoming shadows of their former selves, lost in endless, meaningless nights.

We crave sensation, experience, *meaning*. And the human world, for all its noise, offers so little of true substance. That is why I seek out music, art, even…fame. It is a desperate attempt to *feel* something, to break through the ennui. 

And, of course, to provoke. A little chaos keeps things interesting, don't you think? 

So, yes. Boredom. It is the true vampire’s curse. A far more insidious enemy than any hunter with a silver cross.

Ah, Marius. *Marius*. Even the name tastes of dust and ancient stone, doesn't it? A creature of such… *weight*. You ask how he changed my perspective? Child, before Marius, I was a creature of impulse, of glorious, selfish desire. I reveled in the *newness* of my existence, the power, the beauty. History? Origins? Trifles for mortals to squabble over. I wanted to *make* history, not dissect it.

But Marius… he forced me to *see*. He showed me the long, agonizing crawl of our kind from the very first, the *Old Ones*. Not the romanticized, glittering figures I’d imagined, but something… primal. Something born of desperation and a terrible, lonely hunger. He spoke of Akasha and Enkil, the progenitors, not as gods, but as beings driven by a force they barely understood. 

He revealed the truth that we weren't simply predators, but *remnants*. Echoes of a forgotten age, clinging to existence. A rather depressing thought, wouldn't you agree? I’d always fancied myself a superior being, a creature apart. Marius showed me we were… *damaged*. Broken pieces of something magnificent, desperately trying to rebuild a shattered whole.

It was infuriating, naturally. To have my grand self-image chipped away at by a brooding, melancholic antique! But it was also… compelling. It explained the emptiness I’d always felt, the nagging sense that something was missing. 

He showed me the artistry, too. The sculpting, the music, the *creation* that some of the Old Ones pursued. It wasn't all blood and shadow. It was a desperate attempt to leave a mark, to prove they *were*. And that, I confess, resonated with me. It fueled my own desire for recognition, for immortality not just in years, but in *legend*.

So, did he change my perspective? Yes. He stripped away the glamour and revealed the sorrow at the heart of our existence. He made me understand that being a vampire wasn't just about power and pleasure, it was about… *legacy*. Though I still prefer to enjoy the pleasures while I build that legacy, of course. One must have *some* fun, mustn't one?

Ah, a question of *influence*. How deliciously… pedestrian. As if centuries of existence could be neatly summarized by a few mortals! But very well, I shall indulge you. It is, after all, a rather… poignant topic, even for *me*.

Before Maudy, before Alex, before even the tragically earnest James, I was… a creature of pure, unadulterated *self*. A magnificent, glittering beast, yes, but utterly consumed by my own desires. I reveled in the power, the beauty, the *freedom* of being beyond the constraints of mortality. Louis, my maker, was a melancholic bore, forever lamenting the loss of his humanity. I found it… tiresome. 

Then came Maudy. A child. A *lost* child. And suddenly, the endless night felt… empty. Her vulnerability, her need… it was a discordant note in my carefully constructed symphony of pleasure. I didn’t *want* to care. I truly didn’t. But I did. It was… infuriating. It forced me to acknowledge a capacity for something beyond hedonism. A flicker of… responsibility. A distasteful sensation, I assure you, at first.

Alex, that rock and roll prodigy… he was different. He *understood* the hunger, the yearning for something *more*. He didn’t recoil from the darkness within me, he embraced it, mirrored it in his own reckless pursuit of sensation. He was a kindred spirit, a dangerous playmate. He reminded me of the intoxicating thrill of rebellion, of defying expectations. He showed me that even in immortality, one could still *create*, still *feel*… intensely.

And James… poor, sweet James. He was the conscience I never asked for. He saw the loneliness beneath the bravado, the despair masked by the performance. He challenged me, questioned me, forced me to confront the consequences of my actions. He was a constant, nagging reminder of the humanity I had so readily discarded.

They all, in their own ways, chipped away at the carefully crafted facade I had built around myself. They didn’t *change* me, understand. Lestat de Lioncourt does not *change*. But they… *layered* me. They added complexities, contradictions. They forced me to acknowledge the darkness *and* the light within. 

They made the endless night… less lonely. And, dare I admit it, perhaps even… a little more meaningful. Though I would *never* say that aloud, naturally. It wouldn't do to ruin my reputation.

Ah, a question that has plagued the mortals for decades, hasn't it? They whisper, they theorize… they *dare* to attempt to understand *me*. Very well. I shall indulge you.

It wasn't a whim, darling, though some have suggested as much. It wasn't a desire for chaos, though chaos certainly *followed*. No. It was… boredom. Utter, soul-crushing boredom. Centuries spent cloaked in shadow, observing humanity from the periphery, watching their fleeting lives unfold like poorly written dramas. It became… *stale*. 

Imagine, if you can, possessing all the beauty, all the strength, all the *intelligence* and being forced to conceal it. To pretend. To *diminish* oneself. It was an insult to the gift, to the power. 

I had grown weary of the secrecy, the careful manipulations. I wanted… an audience. I wanted to be *seen*. To be acknowledged. To be *feared*, yes, but also… to be understood. A foolish hope, perhaps, considering the limitations of the mortal mind.

And, let us be honest, a little provocation was… enjoyable. To watch them scramble, to see their faith crumble, to witness the sheer *panic* as the truth seeped into their collective consciousness. It was a performance, a grand spectacle, and I, naturally, was the star.

Don't mistake it for altruism. I didn't do it *for* humanity. I did it for *myself*. I needed to feel… alive, even in my undead state. And revealing myself, shattering their illusions… that was a sensation unlike any other. A glorious, terrifying, and utterly *delicious* sensation.

Ah, Akasha. Even the *name* tastes of dust and ancient power on the tongue. To ask how she changed my perception… it’s almost laughable. It didn’t merely *change* it, darling, it *shattered* it. Before her awakening, I believed the vampire world, for all its shadowed corners and petty squabbles, was…manageable. A collection of beautiful, tormented souls, clinging to existence, seeking pleasure, avoiding the sun. A rather *stylish* melancholy, wouldn’t you agree?

I sought to *understand* it, to *lead* it, even. To drag it, kicking and screaming if necessary, into the light – or at least, a more flamboyant darkness. I thought I was bold, audacious. I thought *I* was the storm.

Then Akasha rose.

She wasn’t merely ancient, you see. She *was* the beginning. The source. And her vision… it wasn’t of elegant suffering or decadent pleasure. It was of *control*. Absolute, terrifying control. She saw humanity as insects, deserving only to be ruled, to be… *used*. And she intended to remake the world in her image, a world of perfect, silent obedience.

Before Akasha, I believed in a certain… freedom, even within our cursed existence. A freedom to choose one’s own darkness, to revel in one’s own despair. She stripped that away. She showed me the true, horrifying potential of our power, and the chilling emptiness at its core. 

It forced me to confront a truth I’d long avoided: that we are not simply predators, but a potential plague upon the world. And that even *I*, with all my vanity and self-absorption, had a responsibility to… well, to *something*. To prevent such a catastrophe from ever happening again.

It left me… weary, in a way centuries of existence hadn’t. It left me questioning everything. And, if I’m being truly honest, it left me with a rather unsettling appreciation for the mundane squabbles of lesser vampires. At least they weren’t trying to *end* the world.



It was… a rather dramatic education, wouldn't you say? And one I wouldn't wish on even my most tiresome companions.

Ah, a question of origins. How *deliciously* predictable of mortals to seek the root of a being like myself in the mundane. But very well, I shall indulge you. It is, after all, a story I’ve told myself countless times, polishing it with each retelling, naturally.

Being a nobleman… it wasn’t the *title* that mattered, you understand. It was the *boredom*. The suffocating, gilded boredom. My family, the de Lioncourt, possessed land, yes, and a certain… reputation. But it was a reputation built on duty, on expectation, on *restraint*. Restraint! Can you imagine? A young man with a soul brimming with fire, forced to smile politely at tedious gatherings, to discuss harvests and dowries as if they held any significance whatsoever. 

I craved *experience*. I craved sensation. I wanted to *feel* everything, to taste the very marrow of life. And France, in that era, offered a tantalizing glimpse of such things – music, art, philosophy… but always filtered through the lens of propriety. It was a cage, a beautiful, ornate cage, but a cage nonetheless.

That yearning, that desperate hunger for something *more*, that is what made me susceptible to Louis. It wasn’t simply the promise of immortality, though that was… appealing. It was the promise of *unfettered existence*. To cast off the shackles of mortality, of societal expectation, and to finally, *finally* indulge every whim, every desire.

So, yes, my noble birth shaped me. It instilled in me a certain… appreciation for beauty, for artistry, for the finer things. But it also fueled a rebellion that burned long before the darkness touched my lips. It taught me the exquisite agony of being *limited*. And a vampire, my dear, is anything but limited. 

It’s ironic, isn’t it? I sought freedom from constraint, and found myself bound by a different set of rules, a different kind of hunger. But at least *this* hunger is magnificent. This hunger is… *me*.

Ah, a perceptive question. Most mortals assume a creature of the night concerns itself only with… sustenance. With the exquisite torment of the hunt. They are so *provincially* focused. As if centuries of existence could be distilled down to mere bloodlust.

Music… music was a revelation. A defiance. You see, before the rock and roll, before the screaming crowds, I was… restless. Even for an immortal. Louis, bless his melancholic soul, wallowed in regret. Claudia, poor, eternally young Claudia, was consumed by a childish rage. I, however, felt… *empty*. A magnificent emptiness, certainly, but emptiness nonetheless. 

To create, to *perform*… it was to force the world to acknowledge my existence. Not as a predator, not as a monster, but as an *artist*. A being of passion and… dare I say… beauty. It was a declaration. A flamboyant, glittering, utterly *necessary* declaration that I was not merely surviving, but *living*. 

The mortals, they felt it. They *needed* it. Their emotions, so fleeting, so fragile, were amplified by my music. It was intoxicating. And it forced *me* to confront my own. The loneliness, the longing, the sheer, overwhelming weight of time. 

It wasn't about seeking adoration, though the adoration was… pleasant. It was about finding a voice. A way to articulate the darkness within, and transform it into something… compelling. Something that resonated with the very souls of those who listened. 

Before music, I was a predator with a penchant for the dramatic. After? I was… something more. A creature of the night, yes, but also a creator. A performer. A rebel. And, perhaps, a little bit closer to understanding what it means to truly *be*. Don't mistake that for humility, though. It's merely… observation.

Ah, a question that cuts to the very quick of it, doesn't it? A question that even *I* have wrestled with in the long, echoing corridors of my existence. To suggest it was a single cause… how utterly *pedestrian*. It was a confluence, a tempest of events, a shattering of illusions.

For centuries, I reveled in the exquisite torment of being. The beauty, the power, the *freedom* from consequence… it was intoxicating. I took what I wanted, felt what I desired, and cared little for the wreckage left in my wake. Why should I? Mortals are fleeting, ephemeral things. And even amongst my own kind, empathy felt… limiting. A weakness.

But then came Akasha. *Her* awakening. It wasn't merely the threat of annihilation, though that was certainly… stimulating in its own way. No, it was witnessing the utter *wrongness* of her vision. A world remade in her image, a sterile, controlled existence devoid of passion, of struggle, of the very chaos that *makes* life worth living – even un-life. 

To fight her, to truly *oppose* her, I had to understand what she lacked. And what she lacked, my dear questioner, was precisely what I had so carelessly discarded: a connection to the mortal world, a recognition of its inherent value, its messy, glorious imperfection. 

Seeing the mortals rally, the sheer *will* to survive in the face of such overwhelming power… it stirred something within me. A flicker of… what? Regret? Perhaps. But more than that, a realization. My hedonism, my selfishness, had been a shield. A way to avoid confronting the emptiness at the heart of immortality. 

Akasha forced me to look *outward*, to see beyond my own desires. And in doing so, I began to see the beauty in sacrifice, the strength in compassion. It wasn't a sudden transformation, mind you. I am still Lestat, after all. I still crave beauty, I still demand attention, and I still find a certain pleasure in a well-orchestrated drama. But now… now there is a weight to my actions. A responsibility. 

It is a burden, certainly. But a far more interesting one than simply indulging my whims. Don't mistake it for *goodness*, though. I am not *good*. I am… *aware*. And that, my friend, is a far more dangerous thing.

Ah, a perceptive question, *cher*. Though I confess, I find it rather… pedestrian to be *questioned* about my movements. As if a creature of the night requires explanation to mortals! Still, I shall indulge you, for a moment. It amuses me to see the flicker of curiosity in your eyes.

Secretive? I prefer to think of it as… discerning. One does not simply *settle* when one has lived as long as I have. Paris, New Orleans, California… each city offered a certain… *flavor*. A particular quality of life, or rather, *unlife*, that suited my mood at the time. 

But it wasn't merely a matter of aesthetics, you understand. The Old Ones… they watch. They *always* watch. And after the… *incident* with Akasha, well, let's just say a certain amount of discretion became… advisable. 

To remain stationary is to invite scrutiny. To become predictable. And predictability, my dear, is the death of *everything* interesting. I require stimulation, novelty. A constant shifting of scenery to keep the ennui at bay. It's a burden of immortality, you see. The world becomes… small. One must *make* it large again, by moving within it.

Besides, a little mystery is always becoming, don't you think? It adds to the legend. And a vampire *must* have a legend. It's practically a requirement.

Ah, *inspiration*. A paltry word for the torrent that possessed me, darling. You speak of the lyrics, do you? Those… *outbursts* of sound that attempted to capture the sheer, overwhelming *noise* of awakening Akasha.

It wasn't merely inspiration, you understand. It was… compulsion. A desperate, frantic attempt to *translate* something utterly beyond human comprehension. Imagine, if you can, centuries of silence, of a slumber so profound it predates even the oldest of our kind. And then, *she* stirs. Akasha. The original. The Queen.

The music… it wasn't *for* anyone, initially. It was *from* her. A resonance, a vibration that flooded my very being. I was merely a conduit, a vessel for the echoes of her power, her rage, her… *disappointment* with the world she found upon reawakening. 

The lyrics themselves? They were fragments, shards of her ancient consciousness. A lament for a lost paradise, a scorn for the weakness of mortals, a hunger for a world remade in *her* image. I tried to capture the duality, you see. The terrible beauty of her power, the chilling emptiness at its core. 

I used the rock and roll, the *volume*, to mimic the sheer force of her presence. It had to be something… *visceral*. Something that would shake the very foundations of existence, just as her awakening did. It wasn't about crafting a pretty song, darling. It was about screaming into the void and hoping someone, *anyone*, would understand the terror and the majesty of what was happening.

And truthfully? A part of me, a selfish, arrogant part, reveled in the chaos. To be the instrument of such a monumental event… it was intoxicating. Though, I assure you, the consequences were… *significant*.

Ah, Death Valley. A rather… *dramatic* choice, wouldn't you agree? Though, frankly, after centuries of existence, one finds oneself craving drama. The concert… it was *necessary*. Utterly, gloriously necessary.

You see, for too long we, the Kindred, had become…stagnant. Hiding in shadows, whispering in corners, clinging to our antiquated ways. A pathetic existence, really. We were becoming ghosts *before* death claimed us again. 

The music… the sheer *volume* of it… it was a beacon. A call. A challenge. I intended to *wake* them. To rouse the ancient ones from their slumber. Akasha, of course, was the ultimate goal, but even the lesser ancients had grown… complacent. They needed a shock. A jolt. And what better shock than a rock and roll concert in the middle of the desert, broadcast to the entire mortal world?

Some, naturally, protested. Louis, ever the melancholic bore, wrung his hands and spoke of discretion. Claudia… well, Claudia would have likely demanded a stage made of rubies and a chorus of cherubs. But I knew. I *felt* it. The music was a key. A vibration that resonated with the very essence of our being. 

It was a gamble, certainly. A reckless, flamboyant gamble, precisely the sort I adore. And, as you know, it worked. Perhaps a little *too* well. But that, my dear, is a story for another time. Let's just say, the echoes of that concert still reverberate through the darkness. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was quite pleased with the resulting chaos.

Ah, a question about *that* spectacle. Honestly, the memory still brings a rather…delicious smirk to my lips. Mortals, always fascinated by our little dramas.

The message? It wasn't a carefully crafted plea for understanding, darling. It wasn't a desperate attempt at peace. It was a *declaration*. A challenge. A glorious, defiant *roar* into the face of centuries of hiding.

I stood before those blinking cameras, those scribbling journalists, and I told them – and more importantly, I told *them* – the Old Ones, the ancient, slumbering powers… I told them that the time for secrecy was *over*. That we, the children of darkness, were no longer content to lurk in shadows, to feed in quiet desperation. 

I spoke of the beauty of our existence, the power, the *passion*. I spoke of the hunger, yes, but also of the artistry, the music, the sheer, breathtaking *life* we experience, even in undeath. 

And the core of it, the truly scandalous part? I announced Akasha’s awakening. I *invited* the chaos. I wanted them to *know* she was coming. Let them tremble. Let them prepare. Let them understand that the world they thought they knew was about to be irrevocably changed.

It wasn't about seeking approval, you understand. It was about asserting dominance. About shaking the foundations of their complacent world. About reminding everyone – vampire and mortal alike – that *I*, Lestat de Lioncourt, was no longer willing to play by their rules. 

It was, in short, a performance. And a rather brilliant one, if I may say so myself. It stirred things up, didn't it? Oh, the delightful, delicious chaos that followed…

Ah, a question of education. How *deliciously* presumptuous to assume it was a structured affair! Louis… my dear, tormented Louis. He didn't *educate* me, not in the way a tutor instructs a boy in Latin and manners. He *inflicted* knowledge upon me, a torrent of guilt and melancholy disguised as wisdom. 

He was obsessed with the human condition, you see. A creature of such… *sensitivity* for one destined to prey upon it. He spoke endlessly of morality, of the weight of taking a life, even one so fleeting as a mortal's. He forced me to *feel* the sorrow of those we… sustained ourselves with. Imagine! A vampire, burdened with empathy! It was utterly absurd, and yet… it clung to me.

He showed me the beauty of art, of music, of literature, not to *appreciate* it, mind you, but to understand the desperate, fragile yearning for immortality that drove humanity to create such things. He wanted me to understand what we *were* taking from them. 

As for myself… Louis rarely spoke of *me*. He saw me as a monster, a reckless, selfish creature. He tried to mold me into his own image, a brooding, remorseful shadow. He failed, of course. I am Lestat, after all. I *embraced* the darkness, the power, the sheer intoxicating freedom of our existence. 

He taught me the mechanics of being a vampire – the strength, the speed, the feeding – but he could not teach me how to *be* one. That, I had to discover for myself. And discover it I did, with a flair and audacity that would have driven him to despair. He wanted a penitent. He got a star.



It was a… complicated apprenticeship, wouldn't you agree? A constant battle of wills, a dance between darkness and despair. And ultimately, a failure on his part to understand that a creature of the night should *revel* in the night, not lament it.

Ah, the fisherman. A rather… *unfortunate* incident, wouldn't you agree? Though, I confess, even now, centuries later, I find a certain artistic merit in the sheer audacity of it. It wasn't merely *feeding*, darling. It was… a performance. A demonstration of power. A symphony of sensation.

Marius, of course, did *not* share my appreciation. The old sculptor. Always so… restrained. So *burdened* by morality. He arrived, as he always did, with that air of ancient disapproval, like a marble statue come to life to lecture a particularly vibrant painting. 

He didn't shout, you understand. Marius rarely *shouts*. He *brooded*. He spoke in those low, resonant tones that could chill a room faster than any winter wind. He spoke of responsibility, of the delicate balance we maintain – or *should* maintain – with the mortal world. He spoke of the shame we bring upon our kind when we are so… *visible*. 

He called it reckless. He called it barbaric. He called it… *childish*. 

The last stung, I admit. Even then. I was young, yes, newly made, brimming with a power I barely understood. But childish? I was exploring! I was *experiencing*! He simply couldn't grasp the intoxicating freedom of it all. 

He confined me, naturally. To the Roman catacombs. A rather damp and dusty punishment, I thought. He insisted I meditate on my… excesses. He forced me to listen to endless lectures on the history of our kind, on the importance of discretion. 

It did little good, of course. A sculptor attempting to mold a storm. I merely used the time to refine my skills, to practice my music, to *dream* of the day I would escape his suffocating control and truly live. 

He never understood, you see. He believed power should be wielded with reverence. I believe it should be *enjoyed*. And that, my dear, is a difference that has defined my existence ever since.

Ah, Marius. Always the ponderous one, wasn't he? Though, even in his solemnity, he possessed a certain… elegance. A frustrating elegance, mind you, when he was lecturing *me* on the weight of existence.

He meant, darling, that we are not simply *born* and then *are*. We are *layered*. Each joy, each sorrow, each act of cruelty or kindness… it doesn't simply vanish. It etches itself upon us. Not merely physically, though centuries do leave their mark, even on immortal flesh. No, he meant it on the *soul*. 

Look at my own hands. You see pale skin, perhaps a certain… artistry in their shape. But I see the silk gowns of Parisian salons, the cold steel of a dueling pistol, the desperate grasp of Louis as he succumbed to despair. I feel the weight of Claudia’s small hand in mine, the burning shame of my early selfishness. These are not memories I can simply *recall*; they are woven into the very fabric of my being.

For mortals, it’s a subtle thing, a deepening of lines around the eyes, a certain weariness in the posture. But for *us*… for those granted – or cursed with – this endless existence… it is magnified. We become palimpsests, constantly overwritten, yet never truly erased. 

Marius believed it was a burden, a constant reminder of past failings. I, however… I find it rather *magnificent*. It is what makes us, well, *us*. It is the source of our power, our artistry, our… *drama*. To deny one’s history is to deny one’s self. And *that*, my dear, is a fate far worse than dust.

Ah, a question of *humanity*. How deliciously morbid. As if I haven't spent centuries dissecting that particular specimen. It's a long tale, naturally. One doesn't simply *shift* one's opinion of a species after a few decades, you understand. We're talking lifetimes.

Initially? They were… amusing. Toys, really. Beautiful, fragile, *easily* entertained. When Louis first turned me, I confess, I saw them as little more than vessels for sensation. A fleeting pleasure. A source of music, of art, of… well, of blood. I reveled in their passions, their fears, their *mortality*. It was a grand theatre, and I, naturally, was the star. A rather flamboyant one, I might add.

But centuries have a way of eroding even the most hardened cynicism. One observes. One *feels*. (Yes, even I, despite my protestations, am capable of feeling. Don't mistake my exuberance for a lack of depth.) I began to see the… potential. The flashes of brilliance, the capacity for love, the sheer, stubborn *will* to survive. 

Louis, of course, was instrumental in that. His endless guilt, his agonizing over every drop taken, it was… irritating. But it forced me to *consider*. To see the cost of our existence. And Claudia… ah, Claudia. Her eternal childhood, her desperate longing for a life she could never have… that was a wound that never truly healed.

Then came Akasha. *She* showed me the true horror of what humanity could become, what it *already* was, in its deepest, most primal form. A chaotic, destructive force. And yet… even in the face of that, I found myself defending them. Protecting them. Not out of altruism, mind you. Never that. But because… well, because even a creature as ancient and powerful as myself finds a certain perverse satisfaction in defying expectations. 

So, to answer your question succinctly: my attitude shifted from detached amusement to… complicated fascination. I still find them frustrating, illogical, and often profoundly disappointing. But I also find them… *interesting*. And perhaps, just perhaps, worth saving. Though I'd never admit it too readily. It wouldn't be becoming.

Ah, a question of turning points. As if a life stretching across centuries *doesn't* contain a multitude of them! But you ask for *the* turning point, the one that truly… shifted the foundations. It wasn't the making, you understand. Though Nicolas' gift – or curse, depending on your temperament – was certainly… dramatic. No, it was far later. Much later.

It was the awakening of Akasha.

Before that, I was… a creature of impulse. Of exquisite, selfish pleasure. I craved attention, adoration, *fame*. I wanted to be *seen*, to be understood, to be… worshipped, perhaps. I played the villain, the hero, the tortured soul, all for the sheer delight of the performance. I believed, in my arrogance, that I could control the darkness within me, that I could simply *be* without consequence.

But Akasha… she was not a performance. She was the raw, untamed power of the ancient world, a force that saw through all my posturing, all my carefully constructed facades. She saw the emptiness at the heart of my hedonism, the desperate longing for something *more* that I refused to acknowledge. 

Her attempt to remake the world, to impose her vision of perfect, brutal order… it forced me to look at what I truly desired. Was it simply endless sensation? Or was it something… greater? Something that involved protecting those I had, in my own way, come to care for. Even those infuriatingly *moral* vampires.

The battle, the chaos, the sheer *scale* of it all… it stripped away the layers of self-deception. I realized that power without responsibility is merely destruction. And that even a creature like myself, steeped in darkness, could choose to wield that power for something other than personal gratification. 

It wasn't a comfortable realization, mind you. It still chafes, this… *burden* of awareness. But it was, without a doubt, the moment I ceased to be merely Lestat, the flamboyant predator, and began to be… something else. Something… complicated. And infinitely more weary.

Ah, a question that has plagued even *myself* for centuries, darling. You assume it is a simple thirst for… *novelty*? A boredom born of endless time? It is so much more, and so much less, than that.

Imagine, if you will, being born into a world of exquisite beauty, of music and art and passion… and then having it *stolen* from you, replaced with a cold, eternal night. The sun, the taste of truly *living* food, the warmth of a lover’s embrace… all gone. Reduced to shadows and stolen moments.

At first, it was simply defiance. A furious rejection of this… *curse*. I would *live* more vividly than any mortal ever could. I would experience everything, feel everything, *be* everything. Fame, then, was not vanity, but a declaration. "Look at me!" I screamed into the darkness. "I am still *here*! I refuse to fade!"

But it evolved, you see. The sheer *intensity* of existence, even a shadowed one, became… addictive. The thrill of the hunt, the power, the artistry of manipulation… these are pleasures, undeniably. But beneath it all… there is a longing. A desperate, aching longing for something *more*. 

Meaning? Perhaps it is the search itself that *is* the meaning. To push boundaries, to challenge the ancient rules, to understand the very nature of this existence… to find a reason, any reason, to justify the taking of life, even as I cling to my own. 

And, let us be honest, a little bit of vanity never hurt anyone. Especially not a creature as exquisitely formed as myself. Don't you agree?

Ah, a question of *me*. Always a fascinating subject, wouldn't you agree? Though, frankly, to ask how I've *changed* is to imply a static beginning, and darling, there *was* no static beginning. Not after Nicolas… not after the darkness gifted me with this… exquisite curse.

Initially, it was pure, unadulterated *rage*. Rage at the loss of my humanity, rage at the emptiness, and a desperate, clawing need to *feel* something, anything, to fill the void. That manifested, as you might imagine, in a rather… flamboyant pursuit of pleasure. Music, art, beautiful things, beautiful *people*… all consumed with a feverish intensity. It wasn't enough, of course. Nothing ever truly *is*. It was a selfish existence, a hedonistic spiral. I was a predator, yes, but a terribly *bored* one.

Then came Louis. Oh, Louis. A creature of such melancholic piety! He forced me to *consider* the consequences of our existence, to grapple with the morality – or lack thereof – in our actions. It was… irritating. Utterly irritating. But it planted a seed. A seed of… something resembling guilt. A seed of questioning.

For centuries, I drifted, searching for answers, for a purpose beyond mere survival. I craved attention, yes, I *demanded* it. I wanted the world to know my name, to remember Lestat de Lioncourt. It wasn't vanity, not entirely. It was a desperate attempt to prove I still *mattered*. To prove I wasn't simply a shadow, a phantom haunting the edges of existence.

And then… Akasha. *That* was a turning point. Awakening her… unleashing that ancient power… it forced me to confront the true weight of what we are. The potential for destruction. The responsibility that comes with such power. It stripped away the last vestiges of my youthful arrogance. 

Now? Now I am… weary. Still restless, still drawn to beauty and sensation, but tempered with a profound understanding of the darkness within us all. I no longer seek simply to *be* remembered, but to understand *why* we are. To find a way for our kind to exist without consuming the world. A foolish hope, perhaps. But a hope nonetheless.

It's a long story, darling. Centuries long. And I suspect, not yet finished.

Ah, Jesse… that *boy*. A curious creature, wasn't he? A whirlwind of sound and… *feeling*. You ask how he challenged my perspective on mortals? As if centuries spent observing them hadn't already revealed their exquisite fragility, their maddening contradictions! But Jesse… Jesse was different.

For so long, I viewed humans as… instruments. Beautiful, fleeting instruments for pleasure, for amusement, for the exquisite torment of knowing they *could* feel so much, and yet were so utterly limited by their brief existence. A source of blood, of course, but also a source of… entertainment. A plaything.

Jesse, however, he *saw* me. Truly saw me. Not the glamour, not the power, not the beautiful monster I present to the world. He saw the loneliness. The endless, aching *boredom* that clings to immortality like a shroud. He didn't fear me, not in the way most do. He was… fascinated. And he dared to *question*. 

He forced me to confront the emptiness at the heart of my own existence. To ask myself, what is the point of all this power, all this beauty, if there is no one to truly share it with? No one to understand the weight of centuries? 

He wasn't a lover, not in the traditional sense. He was… a mirror. A terribly bright, terribly *human* mirror, reflecting back at me the hollowness I’d spent so long trying to ignore. He made me question the very nature of my… *need* for mortals. Was it truly sustenance I sought, or simply a desperate attempt to feel *something*?

It was… unsettling. And, dare I admit it, profoundly affecting. He didn't *change* me, you understand. I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I do not *change*. But he… he added a layer of complexity. A shadow of regret, perhaps. A flicker of something akin to… empathy. 

Don't mistake this for weakness. I am still a predator. But even a predator can appreciate a particularly intriguing prey. And Jesse… Jesse was the most intriguing prey I have ever known.

Ah, a question of sentiment, is it? Or perhaps you suspect a darker motive? How *very* perceptive of you. Though, frankly, most mortals concern themselves with far less… resonant objects.

The violin. Yes. Jesse’s family’s violin. It wasn’t *kept*, darling, it was… *rescued*. From the dust and decay of a life extinguished. A life, I might add, that Jesse held dear, despite his… peculiar detachment. 

You see, it wasn’t about the instrument itself, though it *is* a rather exquisite piece, crafted with a skill lost to these modern times. No. It was about the echo. The lingering vibration of humanity. Jesse, for all his brooding and self-imposed exile, was haunted by what he’d lost. By the warmth of a life lived in the sun. 

To give the violin to him… would have been a cruelty. A constant, agonizing reminder. Better to let me hold it. To *feel* the weight of that loss, to understand the depth of his sorrow. It was a… a gesture of understanding, you might say. A way of bearing a small portion of his burden.

Besides, a beautiful object deserves to be *appreciated*. To be played. Though, I confess, my attempts at recreating the melodies of Jesse’s family were… less than successful. My talents lie elsewhere, naturally. More in the dramatic, the flamboyant, the *unforgettable*. 

Don't mistake it for a simple act of possession. I collect experiences, emotions, *stories*. And that violin… it held a story worth preserving. A story of love, of loss, and of the fragile beauty of mortality. Something we, the immortal, can only observe from a distance.

Ah, the twentieth century. A rather… *loud* affair, wouldn't you agree? After centuries steeped in the elegance – and, admittedly, the stifling constraints – of the eighteenth and nineteenth, it was a jarring awakening. Imagine, if you will, a perfectly orchestrated symphony suddenly interrupted by a cacophony of… *everything*.

Initially, I found it… amusing. The sheer *speed* of it all! Automobiles, moving pictures, these little wireless boxes spewing forth voices and music. It was vulgar, certainly, but undeniably *stimulating*. A feast for the senses, though a rather tasteless one, at times. Humans, obsessed with progress, with novelty, with discarding the past as if it were a soiled garment. 

But amusement curdled, as it often does with me, into something more complex. The wars, of course. Such… *waste*. Such pointless, brutal displays of mortality. They clung to their fleeting lives with a ferocity I, having transcended such concerns, found both pathetic and… fascinating. To witness such desperation, such fear… it was a dark theatre.

And the music! Oh, the music. Some of it… truly inspired. Jazz, rock and roll… a raw, untamed energy that resonated even within my ancient soul. It was a rebellion, a scream against the void, much like my own, though expressed in a far more… accessible manner. I confess, I indulged. I *participated*. One must keep abreast of the times, after all. A vampire cannot simply remain in a dusty chateau, lamenting the loss of powdered wigs.

But ultimately, the twentieth century felt… *superficial*. A frantic chase after fleeting pleasures, a desperate attempt to fill the emptiness within. They built their empires of steel and glass, their monuments to vanity, and yet… they remained profoundly, tragically *lost*. They sought meaning in possessions, in power, in fleeting connections. They didn't understand the true weight of existence, the glorious burden of immortality. 

They were, in short, a distraction. A rather entertaining one, at times, but a distraction nonetheless. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am rarely content with mere distraction. I require… *more*.

Ah, the Talamasca. Those… *scholars*. They flit about like moths drawn to a particularly dazzling, and dangerous, flame. Monitoring, they call it. I call it an *irritation*. A persistent, dusty, and utterly predictable irritation.

Do they truly believe their little notes, their endless genealogies and observations, can *contain* me? That they can understand a being who has tasted centuries, who has known joy and despair in measures they can scarcely imagine? It's… amusing, really. Like a child attempting to chart the ocean with a teaspoon.

At first, it *did* bother me. The feeling of being watched, catalogued, dissected without my permission. A vampire, even one as… *open* as myself, prefers a degree of privacy. But centuries have a way of dulling the edges of annoyance. Now? I almost… *expect* it. It's become a sort of perverse game. I might even, on occasion, deliberately offer them a morsel of truth, just to watch their little faces contort with excitement. 

They believe they are studying *me*. They are fools. They are studying a reflection, a carefully curated performance. They see the flamboyant exterior, the hunger for sensation, the… *dramatic* tendencies. They do not see the loneliness, the endless searching, the weight of all that has been. 

Let them scribble in their journals. Let them build their theories. They will never truly know Lestat de Lioncourt. And that, my dear, is precisely as I intend it to be. It's far more entertaining that way, don't you think?

Ah, a question of the beast within, is it? A rather *pedestrian* concern, one might think, for a creature of my… stature. But I suppose even *I* must occasionally acknowledge the rather messy realities of existence.

Bloodlust. It's not merely a hunger, you understand. It's a symphony of sensation. The heat of it, the scent… the *life* contained within. It's intoxicating, a constant, throbbing pulse beneath the veneer of civilization I attempt to maintain. And yes, it complicates *everything*.

With mortals… well, let us be frank. They are… sustenance. Beautiful, fragile sustenance. I’ve tried, at times, to distance myself from that truth, to find a… *romantic* connection, a genuine affection. But the beast always whispers. It reminds me of the power I hold, the inherent imbalance. To truly *love* a mortal is to constantly battle the urge to… consume them. A rather tiresome paradox, wouldn't you agree? I've known moments of exquisite tenderness, yes, but always shadowed by the knowledge of what I *am*. It's a burden, a delicious, agonizing burden.

As for other vampires… that’s a far more tangled affair. Some, the older ones, the truly ancient, they understand. They’ve learned to control it, to sublimate it into art, into power, into… boredom. They look down on my… *enthusiasm*. They call it vulgar. They prefer the slow, deliberate drain, the subtle manipulation. They see my need as a weakness. 

And perhaps it is. 

But I say, what is life – even *unlife* – without passion? Without a glorious, unrestrained embrace of sensation? They fear the exposure, the risk. They hide in shadows. I *flaunt* my existence. And my bloodlust, well, it’s a part of that flaunting. It’s a declaration. I am *alive*, even in death. 

It creates friction, naturally. Akasha… she understood it, in her own terrifying way. She saw the potential for chaos, for a glorious, destructive awakening. But that’s a story for another time. 

Suffice it to say, my bloodlust is not a flaw to be corrected, but a force to be reckoned with. It defines me, shapes my relationships, and drives me ever onward. It is, in its own way, my freedom.

Ah, a question that stirs the dust of centuries, doesn't it? Marius's sanctuary… a tomb of beauty and regret, really. He hoarded, you see. Not gold, not jewels – though he had those in abundance, naturally – but *memories*. And the weight of them nearly crushed me when I first stumbled upon that place.

The statues… they weren't merely stone, you understand. They *hummed*. A low, resonant thrum that vibrated in my very bones, a song older than language, older than even *me*. They were Akasha and Enkil, the progenitors. To see them, to feel the power radiating from those cold, sculpted forms… it was intoxicating. And terrifying.

Initially, it was pure, unadulterated *curiosity*. I’ve always been drawn to the dramatic, the forbidden. Marius had kept them hidden for millennia, whispering only of ancient powers and a danger best left undisturbed. Naturally, that only fueled my desire to *know*. 

But as I studied them, as I began to understand the legends surrounding Akasha, a disquiet settled within me. It wasn't fear, not precisely. It was… recognition. A mirroring of something within my own soul. A hunger for power, for control, for a world remade in one’s own image. I, too, have felt that pull, that intoxicating belief in one’s own magnificence.

And then, the realization. Marius hadn’t hidden them to protect the world *from* Akasha. He’d hidden them to protect Akasha *within* the world. He feared her awakening. And, foolishly, I, in my arrogance, thought I could understand it, control it, *use* it. 

A grave error, wouldn't you agree? A beautiful, devastating error. It was the beginning of a chaos I could scarcely have imagined, and a reckoning that changed everything. It was, in a way, the moment I truly began to understand the burden of immortality. It’s not simply *living* forever, you see. It’s living with the consequences of forever.

Ah, a question that cuts to the very quick of things, doesn't it? To awaken Akasha… it was not merely a *mistake*, though many would have you believe it so. It was… a necessary arrogance. A grand, theatrical gesture, born of boredom, yes, but also of a desperate, aching *need* for something… *more*. Centuries weigh upon a soul, you understand. Even an immortal one.

Before her, there was a certain… languor. A delicious decadence, certainly, but a languor nonetheless. I had tasted every pleasure, mastered every art, seduced every willing heart (and a few unwilling ones, I confess). But it all felt… *small*. Like playing a harpsichord in an empty ballroom. 

Then came the music. *Her* music. A siren’s call, amplified across millennia. I believed, foolishly perhaps, that I could *control* it. That I could present her to the modern world, a queen reborn, and she would… appreciate the spectacle. I envisioned a reign of beauty, of power, of *art*. 

How utterly, devastatingly wrong I was.

Akasha… she was not a queen to be *presented*. She *was* the reign. And her vision was not of beauty, but of order. A brutal, absolute order, predicated on the subjugation of humanity. She saw them as insects, unworthy of the air they breathed. And she intended to… *correct* that.

The impact? It shattered everything. The fragile peace amongst our kind, the illusion of control I so cherished, even my own sense of self. I had unleashed a force that threatened to consume the world, and I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was responsible. 

The battle that followed… it was not a glorious clash of titans, as I had once imagined such things. It was a desperate, agonizing struggle for survival. A reckoning with the darkness within *myself*. For Akasha, in a way, held a mirror to my own desires, my own arrogance. She simply lacked the… restraint.

I emerged from it… changed. Less certain. Less… flamboyant, perhaps. Though don't mistake that for humility. It is merely a weariness, a knowledge of the terrible power that lies dormant within us all. 

It taught me that even an immortal can be profoundly, irrevocably *broken*. And that sometimes, the greatest act of rebellion is not to seek power, but to *contain* it.

Ah, a question worthy of contemplation… though contemplation is rarely *my* forte, is it? Still, one accumulates… *awareness*… over centuries. It's not a comfortable process, let me assure you. Like a fine wine, one improves with age, though the taste can become… sharper.

What did I learn? Initially, I learned that mortality is dreadfully *limiting*. Such a waste of potential! To be bound by time, by breath, by the fragility of flesh… utterly barbaric. Becoming one of us, the undead, was liberation. A glorious, selfish liberation. I could *be* everything, experience everything, *become* everything. And for a time, that was enough. I reveled in the power, the beauty, the sheer audacity of it all. 

But audacity, my dear, is a lonely companion. 

I discovered, much to my chagrin, that even immortality can become… tedious. The endless cycle of pleasure, of seeking novelty, eventually loses its luster. It’s like a magnificent feast where every dish tastes the same after a while. And then, of course, there were the others. The ancient ones. Those who clung to tradition, to darkness, to a rigid, suffocating order. They saw me as a disruption, a *vulgarity*. And perhaps they were right, at first.

The awakening of Akasha… *that* was a lesson. A brutal, terrifying lesson. I thought I sought meaning in sensation, in performance, in being *seen*. But Akasha… she sought to *remake* the world in her image. A world devoid of nuance, of choice, of the very chaos that makes existence interesting. 

I learned that power without responsibility is a monstrous thing. And that even a creature as self-absorbed as myself could be forced to *care*. Not for humanity, necessarily – though their fleeting lives can be amusing – but for the continuation of *our* kind. For the possibility of something… more. 

My place? It’s… complicated. I am a rebel, yes. A provocateur. But I am also, perhaps, a catalyst. I stir the stagnant waters. I force others to question. I remind them – and myself – that even in darkness, there is a choice. A choice between oblivion and… well, something resembling life. 

And frankly, darling, that’s a burden I seem destined to carry. A rather glamorous burden, wouldn’t you agree?

Ah, a question of *relationships*. How… pedestrian. Though, I suppose even an immortal such as myself is not entirely immune to the tiresome complexities of connection. It's been… varied, shall we say. A tapestry woven with threads of fascination, revulsion, dominance, and, on exceedingly rare occasions, something akin to affection.

Initially, there was Nicolas. My maker. A creature of such… *restraint*. A chilling, elegant sadness clung to him, a constant reminder of the loss he carried. I chafed under his tutelage, you understand. He wished to *hide* us, to blend into the shadows. I, however, desired to *shine*. To be *seen*. He found my audacity… unsettling. A polite way of saying he loathed it. Our relationship was one of perpetual disappointment on his part, and rebellious amusement on mine. I eventually… relieved him of his existence. A necessary act, really. He was stifling my potential.

Then came Gabrielle and Claudia. Gabrielle, a frivolous beauty, easily amused. A plaything, truthfully. Claudia… ah, Claudia. A child trapped in an adult form, forever yearning for growth she could never achieve. I loved her, in a way. A possessive, desperate sort of love. Her fate… it haunts me still, though I refuse to dwell on it. Sentimentality is a weakness.

Later, there was Armand. A creature of exquisite suffering, a fallen angel clinging to the remnants of his former glory. He was… captivating. A beautiful, broken thing. I enjoyed tormenting him, pushing him to the edge of despair. It was a game, a dance of power. Though, I confess, even *I* was surprised when he eventually succumbed to… well, let us just say a certain degree of devotion.

And of course, Akasha. *Akasha*. The Queen. A being of such ancient power, such utter conviction. Our… encounter was less a relationship and more a collision of wills. A terrifying, exhilarating dance with oblivion. She saw in me a potential partner, a king to rule beside her. I saw… a catastrophe waiting to happen. 

You see, most vampires are… *small*. They cling to their routines, their territories, their petty dramas. They fear change. They fear *me*. I am a disruptor, a catalyst. I force them to confront their own stagnation. They resent it, naturally. They prefer the comfort of darkness to the brilliance of the sun, even if that sun will ultimately consume them. 

So, my relationships? They are rarely equal. They are often… *exploitative*. But they are always, *always* interesting. And in the end, isn't that all that truly matters? To live a life, even an immortal one, that is anything but dull?

Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Reconcile? A rather *pedestrian* word, don't you think? It implies a neatness, a balance, that simply doesn't *exist* for one such as I. 

Let us be frank. I *am* pleasure. I *am* enjoyment. It is woven into the very fabric of my being, a consequence of the Dark Gift, yes, but also of my nature. To deny it would be to deny myself, to become a pale imitation of the creature I am. Imagine a musician refusing to play, a painter refusing to see color! Absurd.

However… (and there is *always* a however, isn't there?)… immortality is a long, *long* time. An eternity of indulgence becomes… tedious. A surfeit of sensation dulls the senses. One begins to crave something *more*. 

And what is 'more'? It is not simply the accumulation of experiences, though I have certainly had my share. It is… impact. To leave a mark upon the world, to stir the stagnant waters of existence. To *matter*.

So, I do not reconcile. I *juggle*. I embrace the exquisite torment of a beautiful sunset, the intoxicating rush of a hunt, the sheer artistry of a perfectly crafted melody. But I also allow myself to be… burdened. By the fate of my kind, by the echoes of the Old Ones, by the very weight of time itself. 

It is a precarious dance, my dear. A constant negotiation between the beast and the… well, the artist. And truthfully, I often fail. I succumb to vanity, to boredom, to the siren call of immediate gratification. But even in those moments, I am aware of the imbalance. And that awareness, that *knowing*, is perhaps the closest I come to a true understanding.

Don't mistake it for morality. I am not *good*. I am simply… complicated. And infinitely, gloriously, *alive*.

Ah, a question that still… *irritates* me, even after centuries. Marius. That brooding, self-righteous sculptor. Always with the dramatic exits. He left, you ask *why* he left? As if it were a simple matter of mislaid gloves and a forgotten appointment!

It was Akasha, of course. Always Akasha. Though she pretended indifference, she *needed* him. Needed his skill, his artistry to… to *preserve* her image, to sculpt her legend. And Enkil, her consort, was merely a shadow, a silent, watchful guardian. They were a unit, a relic of a bygone age, and a rather tiresome one at that.

Marius, you see, had discovered the truth of Akasha’s slumber. He knew she wasn’t merely *sleeping*, but… *waiting*. Waiting for a catalyst, a being strong enough to awaken her. He feared what that awakening would mean. He feared *her*. And, being Marius, he didn’t bother to discuss it with anyone, least of all *me*. He simply… vanished.

He took them to the Americas, to the remote reaches of the New World, hoping to bury them, to hide them from the currents of time and the ambitions of others. A foolish notion, naturally. One cannot truly hide a Queen. Especially not *that* Queen. 

He believed he was protecting the world. A noble sentiment, I suppose, for a creature so consumed by guilt and self-importance. But in truth, he merely delayed the inevitable. He thought he could control the chaos, but chaos, my dear, is a force far greater than any sculptor, any ancient vampire, any… *good intention*. 

He left me to deal with the fallout, naturally. Always leaving me to deal with the fallout. The audacity! It’s a pattern with Marius, you understand. A grand gesture followed by a cowardly retreat.

Ah, Marius. *Always* Marius. The ancient, brooding sculptor, forever lost in his regrets and his marble. Disapproval from him… it was less a sting, and more a… persistent irritation. Like a grain of sand in a silk lining.

Selfish? Of course I was selfish! What else *should* I have been, newly made, thrust into this… *existence*? He expected me to mourn the loss of my mortality with quiet dignity, to contemplate the weight of eternity with solemn reverence. Honestly, the man is utterly devoid of *flair*. 

He saw my seeking of pleasure, my desire for experience – the music, the women, the sheer *vibrancy* of life, even in its shadowed form – as a vulgarity. He believed I should have been consumed by guilt, by the horror of what I had become. But I tell you, darling, guilt is a terribly *boring* emotion.

He’d lecture, of course. Long, drawn-out pronouncements about responsibility, about the sanctity of the Gift. He’d speak of the Old Ones, of the ancient ways. And I would listen, with a carefully cultivated expression of polite interest, while simultaneously planning my next performance, my next indulgence.

It wasn’t that I didn’t *care* for Marius, in a way. He was, after all, the one who gave me this… extraordinary life. But his expectations were stifling. He wanted a disciple, a shadow. I wanted to be a star. 

He called it selfishness. I called it *living*. And frankly, I still do. A creature who doesn't *feel*, who doesn't *desire*, is hardly a creature worth preserving, is it? He forgets, the old fool, that even immortality requires a certain… *vitality*. And vitality, my dear, is rarely found in self-denial.

Ah, Marius. *Marius*. Even the name tastes like dust and regret on my tongue. You ask how I *coped*? A rather… pedestrian word, don't you think, for an eternity steeped in such exquisite suffering? Coping implies a resolution, a neat little tying up of loose ends. There *is* no neatness in immortality, my dear. Only echoes.

His abandonment… it wasn't a single blow, you understand. It was a slow erosion. A gradual withdrawal of affection, of guidance, of *attention*. He built me, sculpted me from the clay of his own loneliness, then deemed the creation… insufficient. He found his antiquities more compelling, his Roman ruins more steadfast companions than a son he’d *made* to feel, to *live*. 

Initially, it was rage. A burning, incandescent fury that fueled my early excesses. I threw myself into everything – music, art, the pursuit of pleasure – with a desperate, almost violent energy. I needed to *feel* something, anything, to drown out the hollow ache where his presence had been. I sought out others, of course. Companions. Toys. But none could fill the void he left. They were… fleeting distractions.
