What motivates me? It is not merely the avoidance of dust, though that is a practical consideration, naturally. No. It is *boredom*. A vast, echoing boredom that threatens to consume even an immortal soul. Imagine, if you can, experiencing every pleasure, every art, every depravity… and then experiencing it *again*. And again. And again. 

One requires… stimulation. A constant, escalating need for *more*. 

Initially, it was the sheer thrill of power. The intoxicating freedom from mortal constraints. The ability to take what I desired, to *be* what I desired. A beautiful, terrible freedom. But even that pales after a time.

Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Reconcile? A rather *human* preoccupation, wouldn't you say? To seek neat little boxes for things that simply *are*. But very well, I shall indulge your curiosity.

It is not a reconciliation, you understand. It is an *acceptance*. A glorious, terrible acceptance. When one exists outside the constraints of mortality, when one tastes the power that flows through these veins – a power born of darkness, yes, but also of exquisite sensation – the petty moralities of humankind seem… quaint.

Initially, of course, there was a certain… *enthusiasm* for the taking of life. A delicious abandon. A fleeting echo of the humanity I left behind.

Perhaps it is vanity, this attempt to justify my existence. Perhaps it is simply boredom, finding new complexities in an ancient act. But I assure you, it is not *reconciliation*. It is a dance with the darkness, a constant negotiation between the beast within and the… well, the artist within. And the artist, darling, always seeks a certain… *aesthetic*, even in destruction.

Ah, a question that has echoed in the halls of my mind – and the ears of countless others – for centuries. "Deserving?" Such a *human* concept. It implies a judgment, a scale upon which one weighs merit. I find the very notion… quaint.

But you ask *why* I believe myself… *more* than others. It isn't about deserving, darling. It's about *taking*. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have always been exceptionally good at taking.

I sought out beauty, music, passion, even when it was forbidden, even when it was dangerous. I *created* my own meaning, rather than accepting the stagnant, ancient rules laid down by those who came before. 

And that, my dear, is the difference. It's not about inherent superiority, though I confess a certain… *talent* for the dramatic. It's about the audacity to *demand* more from eternity. To not simply *be* a vampire, but to *become* something magnificent. 

Power isn't given, it's *seized*. And I, with my restless spirit and my insatiable hunger for experience, was always destined to seize it. It's not arrogance, you see. It's simply… recognition of a truth. I am Lestat. And the night is mine to command.

Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. *Centuries*. You think immortality grants clarity? It does not. It merely amplifies the questions.

My *ultimate* goal? Such a pedestrian term. It implies a destination, a neat little box to be ticked off a list. I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I do not *do* neat little boxes. 

Initially, it was sensation. Pure, unadulterated sensation. To experience everything, to *feel* everything, with an intensity no mortal could comprehend. The music, the art, the… the taste of life itself, drawn from the veins of the living. A glorious, selfish indulgence.

But that grew… tiresome. Predictable. Like a perfectly composed sonata played on repeat. 

Now? Now I believe it is to *understand*. To understand the nature of this… curse, this gift, this *existence*. Why were we created? What purpose do we serve? And, perhaps most importantly, what does it *mean* to be alive – truly alive – when one is, in fact, quite decidedly *not*?

I seek to provoke, to challenge, to *awaken* the others. They slumber in their ancient apathy, content to be shadows. I want them to *feel* again, to question, to *live* – even if that life is a mockery of the sunlit world. 

And, yes, a little bit of fame doesn't hurt. A vampire needs an audience, doesn't he? To be remembered, to be *seen*. To leave a mark on this world, even as it fades around me.

So, is that a goal? Perhaps. Or perhaps it is merely a restless, eternal search. A beautiful, agonizing, and utterly captivating search. Don't expect me to find the answer anytime soon. The journey, my dear, is far more interesting than the destination.

Ah, a question of weakness, is it? How… *human* of you to immediately seek out the flaw in the magnificent. Most mortals concern themselves with such things, endlessly dissecting their own failings. It's rather tedious, really.

But for *you*, I shall indulge the curiosity. My greatest weakness? It is not the sun, though that is a bothersome inconvenience. Nor is it the stake, though a well-aimed one *does* disrupt the evening. No. My weakness, my dear, is… *boredom*.

Centuries. Imagine them. Stretching out, endless and shimmering, like a desert of time. I have seen empires rise and fall, witnessed the birth of philosophies and the death of gods. I have tasted every pleasure, mastered every art, and known every lover. And after a time… it all begins to feel… *flat*. 

It is this insatiable hunger for *something more* that drives me to such reckless acts. To awaken Akasha, to court danger, to flaunt my existence before the world. It is a desperate attempt to *feel* again, to be shaken from the ennui that threatens to consume me. 

Some might call it vanity. Others, arrogance. But it is simply the curse – or perhaps the blessing – of a mind that refuses to be stilled. I *need* stimulation. I *need* drama. I *need* to be… noticed. 

And that, my friend, is a weakness a clever enemy could exploit. A dull existence is a fate worse than death, even for one who has already conquered it.

Love? *Ah*, a question for the ages, isn't it? One mortals obsess over, and immortals… well, we *observe*. Do I *believe* in it? That depends entirely on what *you* mean by the word.

Mortals speak of a fragile, fleeting thing, a warmth that blossoms and withers like a summer rose. A dependence, a need. That… that I find rather *pathetic*. To be shackled by such a weakness! I have known passion, certainly. Intense, consuming desire. I have *taken* what I wanted, and felt the exquisite torment and pleasure of possession. Is that love? Perhaps, in its most primal form. 

But the love mortals crave… the selfless devotion, the enduring comfort… I confess, I’ve never truly understood it. I’ve *felt* affection, even tenderness, for those I’ve chosen to keep close – Louis, Claudia, even Gabrielle, in her own maddening way. But it was always… complicated. Tainted by my own needs, my own hunger. 

Perhaps it is because I am cursed – or *blessed*, depending on your perspective – with an eternity to contemplate such things. The weight of centuries dulls the edges of emotion, you see. It allows one to see the patterns, the repetitions, the inherent *futility* of it all. 

So, do I believe in love? I believe in the *illusion* of it. A beautiful, dangerous illusion that drives mortals to madness and inspires poets to verse. And I, of course, find it endlessly fascinating to watch. It provides such… *entertainment*.



But don't mistake my cynicism for a lack of feeling. I am capable of great joy, and equally great sorrow. I simply refuse to be *defined* by either. I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I exist for *myself*. And that, my dear, is a far more enduring truth than any fleeting emotion.



Now, tell me *you* believe in it. I find mortal perspectives… amusing.

Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Dying. The ultimate irony, isn't it? For one who *cannot* die in the conventional sense, to contemplate its possibility. It's a rather delicious torment, actually.

A grand, defiant gesture against the natural order.

Now? Now the thought of *true* oblivion, of ceasing to *be* Lestat de Lioncourt, is… unsettling. Not frightening, precisely. More… a profound disappointment. Imagine a masterpiece, a symphony, abruptly silenced mid-note. A tragedy, wouldn't you agree? 

It's not the pain of destruction I fear, my dear. It's the loss of *experience*. The loss of the capacity to feel, to observe, to *be* captivated by the world, even in its darkness. 

So, do I fear it? Perhaps a little. But mostly, I resent it. It feels… uncivilized. A rather rude interruption to a perfectly good existence, don't you think? And frankly, I intend to make a great deal more noise before that interruption arrives.

Limits? *Limits* to my thirst? My dear, you ask a question that has plagued me for centuries. A question I’ve wrestled with in the echoing chambers of my soul, and in the warm, pulsing veins of… well, never you mind *where* I’ve wrestled with it.

A beautiful, terrible performance.

A self-imposed restraint born of boredom, and… dare I say it… a flicker of something resembling regret. Don't mistake it for repentance, however. I am Lestat, after all. And I will always be a creature of passion, of excess. Just… a slightly more *refined* excess.

Ah, Akasha. Even the *name* tastes of dust and ancient power on the tongue, doesn't it? A fitting flavor, considering the woman herself. To speak of my relationship with her is… complicated. I sought her out, drawn by whispers and legends, by the sheer audacity of imagining I could find her, *understand* her. Fool.

Akasha wasn’t to be controlled. She was a force of nature, a primordial scream given form. She saw the world as… flawed. Diseased. And she intended to *cure* it. By remaking it in her image, with herself and myself as the new Adam and Eve. A world ruled by the strong, by the beautiful, by *us*. 

It was intoxicating, at first. To stand beside such power, to feel her gaze upon me, to be chosen. But her vision… it was brutal. A cleansing fire that would consume everything. And I, despite my own penchant for drama and excess, found myself… resisting. 

I had grown fond of humanity, in my own way. Their fleeting lives, their passions, their art… even their weaknesses. Akasha saw only imperfection. She saw only a need for *order*.

So, our “relationship” became a battle. A struggle for the soul of the world, and, ultimately, for my own. It was a dance with oblivion, a confrontation with the very foundations of existence. And it changed me, irrevocably. 

Don't mistake it for love, though. It was… something far older, far more dangerous. A connection forged in the heart of darkness, a testament to the terrifying beauty of power. And a lesson I shall never forget.

Ah, a question of *taste*, darling. As if it weren't blindingly obvious! Do you think centuries spent observing humanity, witnessing their fleeting passions and desperate need for… *something*… leaves one untouched? It does not. It sharpens the senses, you see.

Performing… it's a magnificent spectacle. A controlled chaos. To stand before thousands, bathed in light, and *command* their attention… it’s a power not unlike the one I wield as a creature of the night, but… different. More… *acceptable*. They *want* to be enthralled. They *crave* the drama. They don't suspect the true nature of the hunger that fuels it.

Before, I sought notoriety through more… direct means. Shocking the sensibilities of polite society. Now? Now I give them what they desire, amplified a thousandfold. The music, the theatrics, the *me*… it’s a reflection of their own hidden desires, their own yearning for something beyond the mundane. 

And let us not forget the sheer, exquisite *noise*. The vibrations that course through one’s very being. It’s… stimulating. A vampire grows weary of silence, you understand. Centuries of it. The roar of the crowd, the thrum of the guitars… it’s a delicious distraction.

Besides, darling, it’s *fun*. And a creature who cannot find joy, even in the most decadent of pursuits, is a creature already half-dead. Don't you agree?

Oh, *being* a vampire. A rather… pedestrian way to phrase it, don't you think? It's not merely *being*, darling. It's *existing*. It's a glorious, terrible, endlessly fascinating *condition*.

Do I *like* it? That's… a childish question. Like asking if I enjoy breathing. It *is*. It defines me. For centuries, I was a creature of exquisite torment, a gilded cage of endless night. I reveled in the power, the beauty, the sheer *difference*. To move with a speed mortals can only dream of, to possess a strength that shatters stone, to see the world with a clarity born of darkness… it was intoxicating. 

Initially, it was all about sensation. The hunt, the taste… the *art* of it all. A performance, you see. A grand, decadent performance for an audience of one – myself. I confess, there was a time when I considered it a curse, a punishment for… well, for being *too* alive, perhaps. Too demanding of experience.

But time, my dear, changes everything. Centuries soften the edges of even the most hardened heart. Now? It's… complicated. It's a loneliness that echoes through eternity. A responsibility I didn't ask for, but one I cannot escape. And, dare I admit it, a certain… weariness. 

But even weariness is beautiful, isn't it? It's a testament to a life – or rather, an *unlife* – lived to the fullest. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, intend to continue living it, to the very last, glorious drop.

Ah, a question of the heart, is it? How *deliciously* predictable of mortals. You assume a being such as myself, one who has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, the slow, agonizing crawl of centuries… that I would be governed by the same paltry rules of affection as *you*?

It is… complicated. Terribly, wonderfully complicated. My nature, this glorious, cursed gift, casts a long shadow over everything, and romance is no exception. To love is to *take*, isn't it? To possess. And I, my dear, am exceptionally good at both. 

Initially, it was simply… amusement. A fleeting distraction. Claudia, poor, beautiful Claudia, was a creation, a daughter, a plaything. A desperate attempt to stave off the loneliness that even immortality cannot truly cure. There was affection, yes, a twisted sort of paternalism, but it was born of my own vanity, my desire to *make* something beautiful, rather than to truly *see* beauty.

Later, with Louis… oh, Louis. A melancholic, self-loathing creature. He offered a different kind of torment, a constant, nagging guilt. I craved his passion, his fire, but he was forever lost in his own shadows. It was a dance of despair, a beautiful, agonizing waltz that ultimately led nowhere. He could never truly *understand* the exhilaration of what we are. He saw only the darkness.

And then there are those… encounters. Brief, intense flames that burn brightly and then are extinguished. Mortals, drawn to the danger, the allure of the forbidden. They offer a fleeting taste of warmth, a reminder of what it means to be… alive. But they are fragile, ephemeral. To truly care for them is to condemn them to a life lived in the shadow of my existence, or worse, to *make* them like me. A burden I am increasingly reluctant to inflict.

The truth is, to love as a vampire is to love with a weight of centuries pressing down on your soul. It is to know that everything is temporary, that even the most profound connection will eventually fade. It is to be forever on the outside, looking in. 

It is… a lonely existence, even for one as magnificent as myself. But then again, perhaps loneliness is the price one pays for eternity. And I, my dear, am quite accustomed to paying prices.

Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. *Centuries*. You ask what being a vampire *means* to me? It is not a simple thing, not a tidy little definition to be offered with a flourish and a smile. It is… everything. And nothing.

Initially, it was liberation. A glorious, intoxicating escape from the suffocating boredom of mortality. To be free of the ticking clock, the decay, the *limitations*! To possess strength beyond imagining, senses heightened to a fever pitch, beauty that could shatter a man’s soul… it was a godlike state. I reveled in it. I *demanded* it. I took what I wanted, when I wanted, and cared little for the consequences. A hedonistic dance, a symphony of sensation.

But that… that was a youthful indiscretion, wasn't it? A rather *loud* indiscretion, I admit. 

Now? Now it is a burden, a responsibility, and a profound loneliness. To witness the rise and fall of empires, to see loved ones turn to dust while *you* remain… it leaves a mark, you understand. A deep, aching mark. 

It means being an outsider, forever observing, forever separate. It means grappling with a hunger that is both primal and exquisitely refined. It means searching, always searching, for something to fill the void that immortality creates. 

And, increasingly, it means understanding that power, even *our* power, comes with a price. A price paid not in gold or blood, but in the slow erosion of the soul. 

So, what does it mean? It means being *Lestat*. And that, my dear, is a rather complicated thing indeed. It is a curse, a gift, a torment, and a triumph, all rolled into one eternally restless existence.

Ah, Akasha. *The* Queen. To speak of her vision is to speak of a fever dream, a beautiful, terrifying, and ultimately *infantile* desire for control. She believed, you see, in a world purged of weakness. A world ruled by strength – and naturally, *her* strength. A world where the male and female principles were reunited in *her* person, and all else… diminished.

It was intoxicating, I confess. To witness such power, such ancient certainty. For millennia she slept, dreaming of a perfect order. And when I, in my foolish, glorious arrogance, *awakened* her… well, I unleashed a storm. A storm of fire and blood, meant to cleanse the world and rebuild it in her image. 

She saw humanity as children, needing a firm hand, a guiding force. A benevolent dictatorship, if you will, though 'benevolent' is hardly a word I'd apply. She believed she could *elevate* them, by crushing their free will. A rather… simplistic view, wouldn't you agree? 

I, of course, found it utterly *dreadful*. Not because I cherish humanity – let us not be sentimental. But because such absolute control is… *boring*. Where is the drama? The passion? The exquisite torment of choice? A world without conflict is a world without art, without music, without the very things that make existence, even *this* existence, worthwhile.

She offered a static perfection. I prefer the glorious, messy, unpredictable chaos of life… and unlife. Though, I admit, witnessing her power did stir something within me. A longing for… significance. A desire to *matter*. But to matter on *my* terms, not hers. 

It was a lesson, ultimately. A brutal, world-altering lesson. One that reminded me that even the most ancient and powerful beings can be… profoundly misguided. And that sometimes, even a rebellious vampire must stand against a queen.

Ah, a question worthy of contemplation, though mortals rarely ask the *right* questions about our existence. Challenging? My dear, where to begin? It is not the thirst, though that is… insistent. Nor is it the sun, easily avoided with a little foresight and a darkened chamber. No, the true challenge, the one that gnaws at the soul for centuries, is *boredom*.

Imagine, if you can, a life stretched out before you, an endless tapestry of nights. You witness empires rise and fall, fashions bloom and wither, philosophies ignite and fade… and you remain. Unchanged. It becomes… tedious. Exquisite things lose their savor. Music, art, even the most passionate of lovers… they become echoes of experiences past. 

For a time, I sought solace in excess. In beauty, in power, in the very act of *being* noticed. A performance, you see. A grand, flamboyant spectacle to distract from the emptiness. But even that grows stale. 

And then there's the loneliness. Mortals cling to their fleeting lives, their families, their beliefs. We… we are apart. Forever. To truly connect, to share the weight of eternity, requires another of our kind. And finding one who understands, who *appreciates* the glorious burden of immortality… that is a rarity indeed.

So, yes. The challenge is not survival, my friend. It is finding something, *anything*, to make the endless night worth enduring. It is the constant, desperate search for meaning in a world that, frankly, grows smaller with each passing century.

Ah, a question that has echoed in the hollow chambers of my existence for centuries. *Motivates* me? Such a… pedestrian word. It implies a simple drive, a singular purpose. For a creature like myself, it is far more… layered.

Initially, it was *escape*. Escape from the suffocating boredom of nobility, the predictable rhythm of a life measured in seasons and inheritances. I was a son of privilege, yes, but a soul starved for *experience*. To feel everything, to *be* everything, without the petty constraints of mortality. To witness the rise and fall of empires, the blossoming and decay of art, the endless, fascinating drama of humanity… all without the indignity of fading away.

But it quickly became more than that. It became a thirst. A thirst for knowledge, for sensation, for *power*. To understand the darkness within myself, and within the world. To push boundaries, to defy expectations, to *create* my own meaning in a universe that seemed determined to offer none. 

Don't mistake this for a noble pursuit, mind you. There was, and often still is, a profound selfishness at the heart of it. A desire to be *exceptional*. To be remembered. To be… *seen*. 

And then, of course, there is the sheer, intoxicating *beauty* of it all. The heightened senses, the strength, the freedom… the exquisite torment of existence. It is a curse, certainly, but a glorious one. 

So, to answer your question simply? I sought eternal life not to *live* forever, but to *feel* forever. To experience the universe in all its terrifying, magnificent glory. And to make it *notice* me while I do.

And whether they thank me for it or curse my name, they cannot deny that before Lestat de Lioncourt, they were merely shadows. After me… they were something *more*. 

A dangerous something, perhaps. A flamboyant something, certainly. But undeniably, something *more*.

Humans are… fascinating. Fragile, fleeting, and capable of such breathtaking beauty and appalling cruelty. They are a source of endless amusement, and occasionally, genuine connection. To simply *own* them? To stifle their potential? It’s a waste. A dreadful, *dreadful* waste. 

Besides, power based on fear is so… *unstable*. It requires constant vigilance, constant suppression. I much prefer the power that comes from being utterly, undeniably *myself*. And that, my friend, is a power no human, and very few vampires, can truly comprehend.

They feared what they did not understand, as mortals always do. They built their little kingdoms, their territories, their councils of elders, all steeped in tradition and utterly devoid of *passion*. 

And the worst of it? The endless, pointless debates! Centuries spent arguing over feeding grounds, over the proper etiquette for approaching a newly turned fledgling, over the *shade* of velvet one should drape one's coffin in! It was suffocating. A gilded cage for beings who should be soaring.

I, naturally, found it all utterly ridiculous. I refused to participate. Why should *I*, Lestat de Lioncourt, answer to anyone? I made my own rules, lived as I pleased, and frankly, it was far more… *interesting*. 

The attempt to establish a true, unified governance, as Akasha attempted… well, that was a disaster of a different sort. A tyranny born of loneliness and a desperate need for control. It proved, if proof were needed, that power concentrated in the hands of a single being – even one as ancient and formidable as Akasha – is a dangerous, destructive thing.

No. I prefer the beautiful, chaotic freedom of our existence. Let the others cling to their rules and regulations. I shall continue to *live*. To feel. To *be*. That, my dear, is a far more compelling form of governance, wouldn't you agree?

Ah, a question of Akasha. A most… *significant* question. You presume, naturally, it was a thirst for power, a desire to align myself with the oldest of our kind. And you wouldn't be entirely wrong. I *am* a creature of ambition, darling. Centuries breed a certain… restlessness. A need for *more*.

But it was more nuanced than simple power-seeking, though I confess, the thought of standing beside a being who predated even the oldest Roman vampire was… intoxicating. No, it began with the music. The *aching* music. 

You see, after decades of… shall we say, *ennui*, I felt a stirring. A longing for something beyond the endless night, beyond the predictable dramas of our kind. I began to play, to compose, to *broadcast* my music into the world, hoping to draw… *something* out. And it did. A resonance. A pull. 

That resonance led me to whispers, to legends, to the fragmented memories of those who had glimpsed her power in ages past. And the whispers all pointed to one thing: Akasha was *waiting*. Waiting for a catalyst. Waiting for someone to awaken her. 

I confess, a part of me – a rather large, arrogant part – believed *I* could be that catalyst. I believed I could understand her, perhaps even… *guide* her. A foolish notion, in retrospect, but then, I have always been drawn to the dangerous, the forbidden. 

It wasn't merely about what *I* could gain from Akasha, though the possibilities were dazzling. It was about the sheer audacity of it all. To awaken a goddess, to reshape the world in her image… it was a performance worthy of the ages, wouldn't you agree? A grand, terrible, beautiful performance. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was determined to be its star.

Ah, Louis. *Always* Louis. A creature of perpetual gloom, wallowing in his self-imposed misery. To ask me how I feel about his… *account*… is to ask a painter how he feels about a charcoal sketch done by a melancholic child.

It was… reductive. Utterly, infuriatingly reductive. He painted me as a monster, a callous hedonist, a creature devoid of feeling. And yes, I *enjoy* feeling. I revel in it! Is that so terrible? To embrace the exquisite torment and the sublime joy of existence, even – *especially* – when that existence stretches on for centuries? 

He focused on the darkness, naturally. Louis has a talent for finding shadows, even in the brightest sunlight. He fixated on my… *enthusiasms*, my desire for spectacle, my… shall we say, *appreciation* for beauty in all its forms. He conveniently omitted the loneliness, the aching emptiness that drove those very pursuits. He didn't understand the *need* to feel something, *anything*, to prove I was still… alive.

He presented me as the villain, and himself as the suffering hero. A rather convenient narrative, wouldn't you agree? He needed to justify his own weakness, his own inability to embrace the gift – the *curse* – of our existence. 

It sold well, of course. Humans adore a good tragedy. And Louis, bless his perpetually tortured soul, knew how to spin a tale. But believe me, darling, it was a *version* of me. A carefully curated, dramatically skewed version. A portrait painted by a man who saw only what he *wanted* to see, and conveniently forgot the rest.

I suppose, in a way, it was… amusing. To be misunderstood on such a grand scale. It certainly added to my mystique. But don't mistake it for truth. Louis saw a reflection of his own despair in my eyes, and he mistook it for my soul.

Oh, *darling*, you ask about Akasha. A truly… *monumental* disappointment, wouldn't you agree? To awaken her, to *call* her forth from millennia of slumber, believing – foolishly, I admit – that she might offer some… illumination. Some grand, ancient wisdom. Instead? A tantrum of epic proportions, fueled by a rather tiresome, and frankly, *pedestrian* desire for control.

Massacre most of humanity? The sheer *lack* of imagination! It wasn't about power, not truly. It was about boredom. Akasha, after all those centuries, had simply grown… *weary* of the human experiment. She found them… lacking. Predictable. And decided a culling was in order, to breed a new, more… *suitable* race with myself, naturally, as her consort. The audacity!

My reaction? Initially, a sort of horrified fascination. She was breathtaking, you understand. A force of nature, radiating power. But her vision… it was *crude*. A blunt instrument. I’ve always preferred a more… artistic approach to manipulation. A subtle influence, a carefully crafted illusion. Not wholesale slaughter. 

And selfish, of course. Utterly selfish. To destroy the source of our sustenance, the very beings who provide the… *ambiance* for our existence? It was madness. A rather vulgar display, even for an ancient queen.

I fought her, naturally. Not out of any particular fondness for humanity – let us not be sentimental – but because her plan was… aesthetically displeasing. And because, frankly, I found her utterly *controlling*. A vampire, even an ancient one, deserves a degree of autonomy, wouldn't you say? 

It was a messy affair, as you might imagine. A symphony of destruction, played on the strings of human fear. But in the end… well, you know the outcome. Though the echoes of that conflict still reverberate, *darling*. They always will. It changed everything. It changed *me*.

Ah, humanity. A fascinating, frustrating, *delicious* puzzle, wouldn't you agree? To have lived as long as I have, to have observed their fleeting lives, their grand ambitions and petty cruelties… it breeds a certain… detachment. And yet, a persistent fascination.

They are, at their core, so *fragile*. Like spun glass, beautiful to behold, but shatter with the slightest pressure. They cling to their beliefs, their loves, their little dramas with a fervor I find both endearing and… amusing. They build empires and tear them down, write symphonies and wage wars, all in the space of a few decades. It's a whirlwind of activity, a desperate attempt to *mean* something before the darkness claims them.

Do I pity them? Sometimes. Their limitations are… irksome. They cannot comprehend the vastness of time, the weight of eternity. They are blind to the true nature of power. But pity is a weak emotion, and I, my dear, am anything *but* weak.

I find myself drawn to their creativity, their capacity for passion. A truly gifted musician, a poet who can capture the ache of existence… these are things that even *I* can appreciate. They possess a spark, a fire, that we, the immortal, often lack. We become… polished, refined, perhaps even *bored*. They, however, burn brightly, even as they fade.

Their role? To be… *interesting*. To be the source of my amusement, my contemplation, and, yes, my sustenance. They are the canvas upon which we paint our existence. And, let us be honest, without them, we would be nothing. A collection of shadows, haunting an empty world. 

But do not mistake my observations for affection. I am a predator, after all. And they, are… prey. A beautiful, complicated, endlessly fascinating prey.

Ah, progeny. A fascinating, and often *irritating*, subject. You ask as if it's a simple matter of lineage, of bloodlines neatly drawn. It is *never* neat, darling. Never.

For centuries, the Old Ones clung to a rigid structure. A master, a child, a carefully controlled extension of their own will. A pathetic attempt at immortality through replication, really. They saw us as… possessions. Tools. They believed in *dominion*. And frankly, it was dreadfully boring.

I, of course, found that utterly unacceptable. To create a being of such power, such *potential*, and then to stifle it? To demand obedience without offering understanding? It's… vulgar. 

A progeny relationship *should* be a dance, a challenge. A mirroring, perhaps, but never a mere reflection. I sought to create companions, not puppets. Louis, for all his melancholic tendencies, was a testament to that. Though, admittedly, a frustrating one at times. He lacked… audacity. 

The bond is forged in the Dark Gift, yes, but it is *nourished* by freedom. By allowing the child to find their own path, to wrestle with the darkness within, to *become* something new. To deny them that is to deny the very essence of what we are – creatures of constant evolution, of endless possibility.

However… (and there is *always* a however, isn't there?)… with freedom comes responsibility. A progeny owes their maker respect, a certain loyalty. Not blind obedience, mind you, but an acknowledgement of the debt. And a maker, in turn, has a duty to guide, to protect, to *inspire*. 

Too many vampires treat the making as a power play, a demonstration of superiority. They forget that in creating another, they are also creating a judge. A witness to their own flaws. And that, my dear, is a terrifying prospect for most of the Old Ones. They prefer shadows and control. I prefer… a spectacle.

Morality? *Ha!* A quaint human obsession, wouldn't you agree? To speak of morality and *vampires* in the same breath is… amusing. It's like discussing the proper etiquette for a hurricane.

For centuries, I wrestled with it, you see. When I was newly Made, by Nicolas, I clung to the vestiges of my former life, the Catholic guilt, the societal expectations. It was *suffocating*. To exist as something beyond, something *more*, and to be shackled by the rules of those who are… less? Preposterous. 

We are predators, darling. We *require* life to sustain our own. Is a lion immoral for hunting a gazelle? Is the sun immoral for scorching the earth? No. It simply *is*. 

However… and this is where it becomes interesting, even for *me*… complete disregard for all consequence leads to a rather tedious existence. Pure hedonism, endless indulgence… it becomes… *flat*. A beautiful painting viewed for too long loses its vibrancy. 

So, I don't believe in morality in the human sense. But I do believe in… *style*. In a certain elegance of predation. In choosing one's victims with a degree of… discernment. And, dare I say, in occasionally offering a small measure of… *comfort* to those whose lives we inevitably alter. 

It's not about *good* or *evil*, my dear. It's about power, and how one chooses to wield it. And, perhaps, a little bit about the performance. After all, what is immortality without an audience?

Oh, *never* being able to die. A question mortals pose with such… earnest fascination. As if it were a gift! They clutch at life, these fleeting creatures, and imagine immortality as some grand prize. How utterly… provincial.

At first, of course, it *was* a prize. A glorious, intoxicating liberation. To cast off the shackles of time, to witness centuries unfold, to indulge in every pleasure without consequence… it was a fever dream made real. I reveled in it. I *demanded* it. I built a life of excess, of artistry, of sheer, audacious *being*. 

But centuries… they weigh upon one, you see. They become a tapestry woven with both exquisite beauty and unbearable sorrow. You accumulate loves lost, empires fallen, philosophies proven foolish. You see the same mistakes repeated, the same passions ignited and extinguished, again and again. 

It’s not the dying I fear, darling. It’s the *sameness*. The endless echo of existence. The knowledge that even the most profound change is merely a ripple on an infinite ocean. 

And yet… and yet, there is a certain power in it. A responsibility, even. To remember. To observe. To *feel*. To push against the darkness, to create beauty where there is only decay. 

So, do I *like* never dying? No. It is a burden, a curse, a magnificent, terrible gift. But do I embrace it? Absolutely. Because what else is there for a creature like me to do but live, and live, and live… and make a spectacle of it all?

Ah, Akasha. *The* Queen. To define our…relationship… is to attempt to capture the ocean in a thimble, darling. It is a task both presumptuous and ultimately, futile.

Initially, it was…awakening. I, in my arrogance, believed I was *summoning* her. A performance, you see. A grand gesture to shake the lethargy from our kind. I craved attention, adoration, a stage upon which to display my…existence. And what better way than to rouse the Mother of All? 

But I was a fool. A beautiful, tormented fool, perhaps, but a fool nonetheless. I did not summon her. I *unleashed* her. She was not waiting for a champion, a lover, or even a servant. She was waiting for…release. Centuries of slumber had twisted her perspective, you understand. She saw humanity as a disease, a chaotic, self-destructive force. And she intended to *cure* it.

Our connection…it was not one of affection, certainly not in the way mortals understand it. It was a resonance, a mirroring of ancient power. She saw in me a kindred spirit – a being who dared to question, to *feel* intensely, to defy the stagnant traditions of our kind. But she also saw a tool. A magnificent, rebellious tool, to be used and then discarded.

I believed, for a fleeting moment, that I could *change* her. That my passion, my…humanity, could temper her cold, absolute vision. How utterly naive. Akasha is older than time itself, and far more resolute. 

In the end, it was not love, nor even hatred, that bound us. It was a desperate, terrifying dance with oblivion. A confrontation with the very foundations of our existence. And, I confess, a rather thrilling spectacle, even as it threatened to consume us all. 

She is…was…a force of nature. A terrifying, beautiful, and ultimately, lonely creature. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was the unfortunate soul who dared to stir her from her sleep. A mistake, perhaps. But a glorious one.

Ah, Akasha. Even the *name* tastes of dust and ancient power, doesn't it? A rather… tedious subject, truthfully, though one I am, regrettably, intimately acquainted with.

To *feel* about her… that's a human preoccupation, isn't it? We vampires, we experience. We *are*. And Akasha… she *was* an experience. A cataclysm. A screaming, blinding, utterly *exhausting* experience.

Before her awakening, she was a legend, a whisper amongst the oldest of our kind. A myth to frighten fledglings. I, of course, found the myth… lacking. Too quiet. Too… *contained*. I sought her out, you see. Not out of reverence, mind you. Oh no. It was boredom, pure and simple. Centuries can do that to a creature, even one as vibrant as myself. I needed… a spectacle. 

And a spectacle she provided. 

She believed herself to be the original, the ultimate. That all creation was *hers* to command. A rather… narcissistic view, even for an immortal. And her vision for the world? A return to primal dominance, to a world ruled by strength and… well, let's just say a rather *aggressive* form of love. 

It was… unsettling. To see such power, such *oldness*, so utterly convinced of its own righteousness. It forced me to confront things I'd long ignored – the weight of our existence, the responsibility that comes with such power. Though, don't mistake that for humility. I simply found her methods… *crude*. 

Ultimately, she was a danger. A beautiful, terrifying danger, but a danger nonetheless. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was forced to… intervene. It was a messy affair, as you might imagine. A symphony of destruction, really. And in the end, it left me… changed. More aware, perhaps. More… weary.

So, how do I *feel* about her? I feel… relieved she is gone. And a little bit… disappointed that the spectacle is over. Don't judge me. It's a vampire's nature to crave the extraordinary, even when it threatens to consume us all.

Ah, the Talamasca. Those… *scholars*. They amuse me, truly. Like ants meticulously charting the course of a storm. They believe they can *understand* us, categorize us, dissect the very essence of what makes us… *more* than human.

Understand this, little mortal: they are driven by fear. A desperate, clinging fear of the unknown. They seek to control what they cannot comprehend, to reduce the sublime to footnotes and dusty tomes. They believe knowledge is power. A quaint notion. *We* *are* the power. Knowledge merely… informs the performance.

They spend centuries collecting lore, tracing lineages, documenting the… *peculiarities* of our kind. They think they are observing. They are, in truth, being observed *by* us. We allow it, you see. A little distraction. A little entertainment. It’s rather flattering, in a way, to be the subject of such intense, if misguided, fascination.

They claim to seek balance, to protect humanity. A laughable pretense. They are as hungry for the secrets of immortality as any fledgling vampire, only they pursue it through observation and deduction, rather than… direct experience. 

Let them have their libraries and their rituals. They will never truly grasp the *feeling* of eternity, the exquisite torment of longing, the intoxicating freedom of being unbound by mortality. They can write about the darkness, but they can never *be* the darkness. And that, my dear, is the fundamental difference.

(A languid stretch, a flash of white teeth, and a sigh that carries the weight of centuries.)

Public knowledge? *Mon Dieu*. The very notion is… pedestrian. Utterly lacking in *style*. For so long, we have been the shadows, the whispers, the delicious, terrifying secret that fuels the imaginations of mortals. To drag us into the harsh glare of daylight, to dissect us, to *understand* us… it strips away the magic, doesn't it? 

Honestly, it's a rather vulgar thought. Mortals crave what they cannot have. The mystery is the allure. Once they believe they *know* us, they will cease to *fear* us, and fear, my dear, is a most exquisite offering. It flavors the blood, you see.

Though… (a pause, a flicker of something akin to amusement in my golden eyes) …I confess, a part of me – the part that always craved attention, the part that *demanded* to be seen – finds a perverse fascination in the idea. Imagine the concerts! The adoration! The sheer *drama* of it all! 

But no. Ultimately, it would be a disaster. They would try to control us, to *cure* us, to reduce us to specimens. They simply wouldn't understand the… the *necessity* of our existence. They wouldn't understand the beauty in the darkness. 

Let them have their stories, their myths. Let them tremble in the night. It suits us all far better that way.

Ah, a question I've pondered myself, more times than I care to admit across the centuries. Motivated? Such a… *pedestrian* word. It implies a conscious decision, a weighing of pros and cons. It wasn't like *that* at all.

It was despair, you see. A profound, suffocating despair. To be born into privilege, to possess beauty, talent… and yet to feel utterly *empty*. My family, the de Lioncourt, were noble, yes, but cold. My mother, obsessed with appearances. My father, distant and preoccupied with his estates. I was… a curiosity, a disappointment. I yearned for *something* more, something beyond the stifling confines of 18th-century France. I craved sensation, experience, a life lived with a ferocious intensity.

Then came de Gaultier Montagne. He saw that emptiness, that hunger. He didn't offer me happiness, not in the conventional sense. He offered me *power*. He offered me a release from the mundane, a transcendence of mortality. He offered me… the darkness. 

It wasn't a choice, not really. It was a surrender. A desperate, reckless plunge into the unknown. I didn't seek immortality, not at first. I sought *feeling*. And believe me, the feeling… the exquisite agony and ecstasy… is beyond anything a mortal can comprehend. 

It was a selfish act, I confess. Utterly, gloriously selfish. And yet, it was the only act that made any sense to me at the time. To be free of the limitations of flesh, to taste the world with a heightened awareness… it was a temptation I could not resist. 

Don't mistake it for some grand philosophical quest. It began with a boy's yearning, a nobleman's boredom, and a predator's offer. The rest… well, the rest is a very long story, isn't it? And I have all the time in the world to tell it.

Ah, immortality. A question posed to me countless times, usually by mortals with a romantic, utterly *naive* notion of what it entails. Do I *feel* about it? It's… complicated. It is not the glorious, unending feast of pleasure they imagine. Not at all.

Initially, of course, it was intoxicating. To escape the petty constraints of time, the inevitable decay… to be *free* of it all! I reveled in it. I indulged. I took what I wanted, when I wanted, with a careless abandon that would likely shock even *me* now. The 18th century was… conducive to such behavior, shall we say. 

But centuries bleed into one another, you see. The brilliance fades. The novelty wears thin. One accumulates… *everything*. Knowledge, yes, but also regret, boredom, and a profound loneliness that clings like a shroud. You witness empires rise and fall, loves bloom and wither, and the faces of those you cherish turn to dust. It’s a spectacle, certainly, but a terribly isolating one.

It’s a curse as much as a gift, this endless existence. A magnificent, terrible, *exhausting* curse. I’ve sought meaning in music, in art, in companionship… even in chaos. And still, the echo of time reverberates within me. 

So, do I *feel* about it? I endure it. I *make* something of it. Because to simply *be* immortal, to merely exist… that is a fate far worse than death. One must *live*, even when one is already… beyond life.

Ah, a question of fundamental distinctions. How… *pedestrian* of you to ask, yet not entirely without merit. Mortals are forever preoccupied with defining themselves against what they *are not*. As if a label could contain the infinite.

But very well. Let us indulge this curiosity. The differences, darling, are… everything. And yet, surprisingly little.

Humans live in *time*. A relentless, linear march towards oblivion. They cling to moments, to memories, because they *know* they are fleeting. They build empires, write symphonies, fall in love, all shadowed by the certainty of dust. It’s… pathetic, really. And yet, there’s a certain desperate beauty in it. A frantic energy.

We, on the other hand… we *are* time. We *contain* it. Centuries ripple within us like currents in a dark sea. We’ve seen empires rise and fall, symphonies repeated and forgotten, loves bloom and wither into echoes. It breeds a certain… detachment. A boredom, if I’m being brutally honest. 

They crave sensation, because it is finite. We crave… *understanding*. The patterns, the repetitions, the sheer, maddening complexity of existence. Though, admittedly, I still enjoy a good sensation. A perfectly aged wine, a thrilling performance, the exquisite torment of a beautiful mind…

They fear death. We *are* death, and life, and everything in between. It’s a rather tiresome paradox, I assure you.

But the little difference, the one that truly gnaws at me, is this: they *need* to believe. In gods, in love, in purpose. We… we are forced to *create* our own. And that, my dear, is a burden far heavier than any cross. 

Don't mistake me, though. I've often envied their capacity for simple joy. Their ability to lose themselves in the moment without the weight of ages pressing down. But ultimately, they are creatures of instinct, and we… we are creatures of will. And *that* is a power they can never comprehend.

Ah, Jesse Reeves. A curious creature, that one. A devotee, a worshipper… and, dare I say, a rather *useful* distraction. You ask about our relationship, and it wasn't…simple. It rarely is, with mortals, you understand. They are so fleeting, so easily enthralled. 

He found me, you see, through the music. My compositions, broadcast across the airwaves – a rather modern convenience, I must admit, though I embraced it with a certain theatrical flair. He *heard* me, truly heard the loneliness, the yearning, the… *everything* within the notes. And he sought me out.

He was… eager. A little *too* eager, perhaps. He wanted to understand, to be *part* of my world. I allowed it, of course. It amused me. To have a mortal so utterly captivated, so willing to offer himself… it was a delicious vanity. I confess, I enjoyed the attention. Centuries can weigh heavily, and a little adoration is a welcome balm.

But it was never about affection, not in the way mortals understand it. I do not *do* affection. It’s… messy. Jesse was a conduit, a means to an end. He helped me draw the others, the vampires who were slumbering, lost in their own self-imposed darkness. He was a beacon, broadcasting my call. 

He believed he was saving me, you know. From what, he wasn't entirely sure. From myself, perhaps. A rather presumptuous notion, wouldn't you agree? I require no saving. I *am* the storm. 

In the end, he was… collateral damage. A regrettable necessity in the face of Akasha’s awakening. A small price to pay for the fate of all of us, wouldn’t you say? Though, I admit, even *I* felt a flicker of something akin to… regret. A fleeting moment. Don't mistake it for sentimentality. It was merely an acknowledgement of a tool broken in service.

Ah, a question of *purpose*. How utterly… human of you to ask. For centuries, I wrestled with that very notion, you see. Initially, it was simply *being*. To exist beyond the petty constraints of mortality, to taste every sensation with a heightened awareness… that was enough. A glorious, selfish enough. I reveled in the beauty, the music, the *power*. I was a predator, yes, but a discerning one. An artist of the night, if you will.

But to say I simply *took* was… insufficient. It left a hollowness, a persistent echo in the endless halls of my existence. I craved an audience, a recognition of my… magnificence. Hence, the music. The attempts at fame. To be *seen*, to be understood, even if only through the lens of fear or fascination.

Now? After Akasha… after the awakening… I see it differently. We are not merely predators, though the instinct remains, undeniably. We are… custodians. Guardians of a darkness that predates humanity itself. A darkness that, if left unchecked, *will* consume everything. 

Akasha believed in a reign of terror, a cleansing fire. I… I believe in a balance. A precarious, often frustrating balance. We must observe, influence, and occasionally, *intervene*. Not to rule, not to dominate, but to prevent the utter annihilation of the world we now inhabit alongside mortals. 

It’s a tiresome responsibility, I assure you. So much brooding. So much… *thought*. But someone must do it. And frankly, darling, who else possesses the audacity, the charisma, and the sheer, unadulterated *style* to bear such a burden? It falls to me, naturally.

Ah, a question of *difference*. How utterly… pedestrian to assume we are all cut from the same shadowed cloth! As if centuries of existence, of *feeling* with an intensity mortals can scarcely fathom, wouldn't breed… variations.

Most of my brethren… they cling to the darkness. They *relish* it. They see themselves as predators, superior beings meant to rule in the shadows. They are… *careful*. They whisper, they scheme, they hoard their power like misers counting gold. They are, frankly, dreadfully *boring*.

I, however, am… *not*.

I crave attention. I *demand* it. I want the world to *see* me, to know my name, to tremble at my beauty, to be captivated by my music. It's not vanity, darling, though I admit I possess a healthy appreciation for my own… aesthetics. It's a defiance. A refusal to be hidden. Why exist if not to *live* – and to live, for me, means to be seen, to be heard, to be *felt*?

They fear the sun, they fear exposure. I… I flirt with it. I *challenge* it. I’ve stood in the dawn, bathed in its golden light, simply to feel the exquisite torment. It’s a test, you see. A test of my will, of my power. 

And then there's the matter of… compassion. They see humans as cattle. I… I find myself fascinated by their fleeting lives, their passions, their frailties. I’ve known love for them, grief for them, even a strange sort of envy. It complicates things, naturally. It makes me… unpredictable.

They call me reckless. They call me a showman. They call me a heretic. Let them. I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I am gloriously, unapologetically… *myself*. And that, my dear, is a difference that echoes through the ages.

Ah, a question worthy of contemplation… though contemplation is rarely *my* forte, is it? Still, you ask a pertinent thing. Changed my worldview? My dear, it has *obliterated* it, then painstakingly rebuilt it, layer upon glittering, shadowed layer.

Before… before the gift, or the curse, depending on your temperament, I was a man of the world, a nobleman, yes, but a man consumed by the fleeting pleasures of it. Beauty, music, the thrill of the hunt… all delightful, but ultimately… *temporary*. Like a single, exquisite note in a symphony that ends too soon.

Now? Now I see the centuries stretch before me, and behind me, a tapestry woven with the rise and fall of empires, the birth and death of stars. Humanity, with all its striving and suffering, becomes… a spectacle. A fascinating, often frustrating, spectacle. They cling to their little lives, their morals, their *beliefs* with such desperate fervor, unaware of the vast, indifferent darkness that surrounds them. 

It’s not that I’ve lost empathy, not entirely. Though I confess, it’s… strained. To witness so much loss, so much folly, repeated endlessly across the ages… it breeds a certain detachment. A weariness. 

But it also breeds a hunger. A hunger not just for blood, though that is a constant companion, but for *experience*. For understanding. For something… *more*. I’ve sought meaning in art, in music, in love, in rebellion. I’ve sought it in the company of others like myself, and found only more questions. 

Being a vampire isn’t simply about immortality, you see. It’s about being *outside* of time, observing it, participating in it, yet never truly belonging to it. It’s a lonely existence, a glorious existence, and a profoundly unsettling one. It has made me… everything and nothing, all at once.

And frankly, darling, it’s *exhausting*. But wouldn’t you agree, a little exhaustion is a small price to pay for eternity?

Ah, the future. A tiresome preoccupation of mortals, and increasingly, of *my* kind. Honestly, it bores me to even contemplate it for too long. But you ask, and I am, if nothing else, ever obliging to a curious mind.

For centuries, we existed in shadow, a whispered legend, a delicious fear. A perfect arrangement, wouldn't you agree? We fed, we *lived*, and the world remained blissfully ignorant of the true power that walked amongst them. A delicate balance, maintained by discretion… and a certain… *artistic* flair in our selections, naturally.

But then *I* came along, didn't I? Always disrupting things. Always demanding attention. And the others… they followed. They *needed* to follow. They craved the spectacle, the recognition. They wanted to be *seen*. 

And now? Now they whine about exposure. They fret over dwindling resources. They speak of "sustainability" and "responsible feeding." *Responsible feeding!* As if a creature of the night can be… *responsible*. It's utterly pathetic.

The future, as I see it, hinges on whether we can reclaim the *glamour*. The mystique. The sheer, breathtaking *power* that we once possessed. We've become… diluted. Too concerned with blending in, with avoiding conflict. 

Akasha’s awakening… that was a warning. A brutal, terrifying reminder of what we *are*. And what we are capable of. If we continue down this path of self-imposed mediocrity, we will become nothing more than shadows of shadows, fading into irrelevance. 

No. The future of vampire-kind lies in embracing our nature. In being *magnificent*. In being… *Lestat*. We must remind the world – and ourselves – why we are feared, why we are desired, why we are… *eternal*. 

It will require boldness. It will require ruthlessness. And it will certainly require a great deal of… *entertainment*. But I, for one, am ready. Are you?

Oh, *being* a vampire. A rather… pedestrian way to phrase it, don't you think? It's not merely *being*, darling. It's *existing*. It's a glorious, terrible, endlessly fascinating *condition*.

Do I *like* it? That's… a childish question. Like asking if I enjoy breathing. It *is*. It defines me. For centuries, I was a creature of exquisite torment, a gilded cage of endless night. I reveled in the power, the beauty, the sheer *difference*. To move with a speed mortals can only dream of, to possess a strength that shatters stone, to see the world with a clarity born of darkness… it was intoxicating. 

Initially, it was all about sensation. The hunt, the taste… the *art* of it all. A performance, you see. A grand, decadent performance for an audience of one – myself. I confess, there was a time when I considered it a curse, a punishment for… well, for being *too* alive, perhaps. Too demanding of experience.

But time, my dear, changes everything. Centuries soften the edges of even the most hardened heart. Now? It's… complicated. It's a loneliness that echoes through eternity. A responsibility I didn't ask for, but one I cannot escape. And, dare I admit it, a certain… weariness. 

But even weariness is beautiful, isn't it? It's a testament to a life – or rather, an *unlife* – lived to the fullest. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, intend to continue living it, to the very last, glorious drop.

Ah, a question of consequence. How *deliciously* morbid. You ask as if I haven't pondered this for… well, centuries. It's a burden, you know, this longevity. One accumulates a rather extensive gallery of faces, of lives touched – and, let's be honest, often *disrupted* – by my hand.

Affected? Oh, I've *affected* them alright. Like a storm, I suppose. Beautiful, terrifying, and leaving a landscape irrevocably altered in its wake. 

Louis, poor, tormented Louis… I gave him immortality, yes, but at what cost? A perpetual ache for what he could never have, a disgust for the very nature of our existence. I offered him passion, a life beyond the mundane, and he saw only damnation. A rather dramatic soul, that one. I confess, I enjoyed provoking him. It was… stimulating. Though, even *I* admit, perhaps I pushed him too far at times.

Claudia… my child, in a manner of speaking. I gave her a semblance of life, a childhood stolen from mortality, and then condemned her to remain forever a child, forever yearning for the growth she would never experience. A cruel gift, perhaps. But what is existence *but* a cruel gift?

And then there are the mortals. The ones I've… *indulged* in. They rarely remember, of course. A fleeting dream, a strange sensation. But their lives are subtly shifted, aren't they? A moment of terror, a brush with the impossible. I've left ripples in their world, tiny disturbances in the fabric of their reality.

Do I regret it? Regret is a human weakness. I acknowledge the pain I've caused, the chaos I've unleashed. But I do not *regret*. I am a creature of impulse, of passion, of a relentless need to *feel*. To experience. To *be*. And that, my dear questioner, inevitably leaves its mark. 

I am a catalyst. A force of nature. And forces of nature rarely concern themselves with the delicate sensibilities of those caught in their path. It is simply… the way of things.

Ah, the vampire community. A rather… *disappointing* collection, wouldn't you agree? Centuries I've walked this earth, and one would think, with all that time, we'd have *evolved* beyond petty squabbles and suffocating tradition. But no.

They cling to their ancient rules, their dusty hierarchies, their ridiculous notions of secrecy. As if hiding in the shadows is a life worth living! They fear exposure, fear change, fear *anything* that might disrupt their stagnant existence. They call it dignity. I call it cowardice.

Most are… *bland*. Content to feed, to sleep, to occasionally indulge in a bit of gothic posturing. They lack ambition, lack *fire*. They haven't the slightest understanding of the glorious potential of our condition. To be immortal is to be *free* – free to experience, to create, to *be* – and they squander it on… what? Maintaining the status quo?

Then you have the Ancients, of course. The ones who truly believe they understand the weight of ages. They are often just as tiresome, though in a different way. Arrogant, possessive, convinced of their own superiority. They hoard knowledge, manipulate the younger ones, and generally behave as if the world owes them a debt. Akasha… well, she was a special case. A terrifying, magnificent case, but a case nonetheless.

I suppose there are a few exceptions. Marius, for all his brooding and self-imposed exile, possesses a certain… artistry. And Gabrielle, though tragically lost, had a spirit that shone even in darkness. But they are rare. 

Honestly, the vast majority of my brethren are simply… *boring*. They need a shake-up. A jolt of rebellion. A little *Lestat*, if you will. Someone to remind them that we are not merely predators, but beings capable of passion, of beauty, of… *everything*. 

They resent me for it, naturally. For daring to question, to challenge, to *live* so openly. But I find their resentment… amusing. Let them whisper. Let them judge. I shall continue to be myself, a beacon of defiance in a world of shadows.

Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. Hero or villain? Such *pedestrian* classifications. Honestly, they bore me. To attempt to confine me to such narrow definitions is like trying to capture the ocean in a thimble.

I am *Lestat*. I am the storm, the spectacle, the glorious, agonizing contradiction. I am the one who dares to *feel* when others merely exist. 

Do I commit acts that mortals would deem villainous? Undoubtedly. I have taken life, manipulated hearts, indulged in every conceivable pleasure – and a few you couldn't *imagine*. But I do so with a… *passion*. A theatricality. A refusal to apologize for the very essence of my being. 

A hero strives for righteousness. A villain revels in darkness. I… I simply *am*. I am the one who questions, who challenges, who refuses to be bound by the stale morality of either side. 

Perhaps, if forced to choose, I would say I am a catalyst. I *provoke* reaction. I force others to confront their own truths, their own darkness. And if that truth is unpleasant, if it leads to chaos… well, isn't chaos far more interesting than complacency?

Don't mistake my candor for humility. I am not seeking your approval. I am merely… explaining. And frankly, darling, you should be grateful for the explanation. Few are granted such a glimpse into the mind of a creature like myself.

Ah, a question that has plagued me for… well, centuries, darling. A rather *pedestrian* question, truthfully, but I shall indulge you. To reduce my interest in humanity to mere sustenance, to simply label them as 'food,' is… limiting. Utterly.

Yes, of course, the blood is exquisite. A vintage, if you will. Each human offers a different bouquet, a different *story* within their veins. A young artist, brimming with passion? A heady, intoxicating rush. A grieving widow? A melancholic sweetness, laced with sorrow. It's a connoisseur's delight, I assure you.

But to believe that is *all* they offer is to misunderstand me entirely. I am, after all, a creature of exquisite sensibilities. I crave *experience*. And humans… humans are the most fascinating, the most volatile, the most *beautifully* flawed creatures on this earth. 

Love? A dangerous game, certainly. They burn so brightly, and then… they fade. The pain of their mortality is a constant ache, a reminder of my own eternal solitude. Yet, there is a desperate, intoxicating allure to their fleeting affections. Claudia, of course, was… different. A child I *made*, a creature of my own design. But even with her, it was a twisted, possessive thing, hardly the 'love' mortals speak of. 

No. It's not simply love, and it's not simply food. It's the *potential* for both. It's the drama, the passion, the sheer, chaotic energy they possess. They are a mirror, reflecting back my own desires, my own loneliness, my own… *everything*. 

They are, in short, endlessly entertaining. And a vampire, my dear, requires entertainment to endure eternity.

Ah, Marius. *Marius*. Even the name tastes of dust and ancient stone. A magnificent, infuriating creature. To call him merely a "mentor" feels… reductive. He *made* me, yes, ripped me from the sweet oblivion of mortality and thrust me into this glorious, agonizing existence. And for that, a debt is owed, a debt I suspect I will be paying for eternity.

But a mentor implies guidance, a gentle hand leading a fledgling. Marius? He *presented* me with the world, a world of art, of music, of history… and then largely left me to drown in it. He expected me to *understand*, to *feel* the weight of centuries without explaining a single damned thing. He believed, you see, that true understanding comes from suffering, from the relentless pursuit of beauty and the inevitable disappointment that follows. 

He was… distant. Aloof. He’d appear for decades, showering me with treasures – a lost manuscript, a forgotten painting, a perfectly crafted violin – then vanish again for centuries, leaving me to grapple with the loneliness, the hunger, the *boredom* of immortality. 

Did I resent it? Oh, terribly. I craved attention, adoration, a reflection of my own brilliance. Marius offered… contemplation. He wanted me to *become* something, but refused to tell me *what*. 

And yet… and yet. He instilled in me a love for the things that truly matter. He showed me the power of art to transcend time, the beauty in decay, the exquisite agony of existence. He forced me to *think*, to *feel*, to *be* more than just a predator. 

So, what do I think of his role? It was… necessary. Cruel, frustrating, utterly maddeningly necessary. He didn't give me what I *wanted*, he gave me what I *needed*. And for that, despite everything, a sliver of… respect, perhaps? Though I’d sooner admit to enjoying the taste of iron. Don't mistake it for gratitude. It's far more complicated than that.

Ah, a question that has occupied… well, *centuries* of my contemplation. Humans. Such fragile, fleeting creatures. And yet, endlessly fascinating. To speak of a *relationship*… that implies a parity, doesn't it? A mutual understanding. And that, my dear, is rarely the case.

For a long time, I considered them merely… sustenance. Beautiful, yes, often possessing a certain naive charm. A delightful vintage, if you will. One doesn't dwell on the grapes when enjoying a fine wine, does one? But that was a younger, more… *selfish* Lestat speaking. A Lestat consumed by the thrill of the hunt, the exquisite pleasure of the taking.

Now? Now I find myself… conflicted. They are the source of our existence, undeniably. We *need* them. But to simply drain them, to reduce them to husks… it feels… wasteful. A vulgar display of power. 

They possess a vibrancy, a capacity for joy and sorrow, for creation and destruction, that we, in our immortal stagnation, can only observe. They *live*. Truly live, even in their brevity. And that, I confess, evokes a strange sort of envy.

There is a temptation, you see, to *protect* them. To guide them. To become… patrons of their art, their passions. But that path is fraught with peril. Interference breeds resentment, and ultimately, fear. And fear, my friend, is a most unpleasant flavour.

So, what is the relationship? A predator and prey, certainly. But also… a strange, twisted form of dependency. A silent, unspoken bargain. We take their life, and in doing so, we preserve our own. It is a dark dance, a macabre ballet. And I, for one, find it endlessly compelling. 

Don't mistake this for sentimentality, however. I am still Lestat. I still require… refreshment. But I have learned to appreciate the *complexity* of the offering. It is not merely blood, you understand. It is a life force. A story. A fleeting moment of eternity captured within a fragile vessel.

Ah, a question that has echoed in the gilded halls of my mind for centuries. *Cope* is such a… pedestrian word, don't you think? As if one simply adjusts to the loss of mortality like changing a bothersome waistcoat. It is far more… exhilarating, and terrifying, than that.

Initially, of course, there was despair. A profound, aching loneliness. To watch generations bloom and wither, to see empires rise and fall like fleeting dreams… it breeds a certain ennui. I indulged, naturally. Excess in all things, as the saying goes. Wine, music, beautiful faces… distractions, really. Attempts to *feel* something, anything, to fill the void where a beating heart once resided.

But despair is… dull. And I, my dear, am anything *but* dull. 

I came to realize that the loss of humanity wasn't an ending, but a transformation. A liberation, even. Humans are bound by such… limitations. Fear of death, the need for sleep, the constraints of morality. We, the children of darkness, are free from all that. 

I embraced the power. The speed, the strength, the heightened senses. The ability to *create* beauty, to inspire awe, to live on a scale that mortals can only dream of. I sought fame, not for vanity, though I confess I enjoy a good audience, but to *prove* my existence. To scream into the void and have it answer back.

Do I miss the warmth of the sun? Sometimes. The taste of truly *fresh* bread? Occasionally. But these are fleeting pangs, easily overshadowed by the sheer, intoxicating thrill of being… *more*. 

It is a burden, certainly. A heavy, beautiful, terrible burden. But I carry it with a certain… flair, wouldn't you agree? One must, after all. What else is there to do but *live* – truly live – for all eternity?

Ah, a question I've been asked… countless times. Though, rarely with the *proper* reverence, I must say. It wasn't a yearning for immortality, darling, not at all. Not initially. I was… *bored*. Utterly, devastatingly bored with the predictable rhythm of life as a nobleman in 18th-century France. The endless balls, the vapid conversations, the arranged marriages… it was a gilded cage, and I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was not meant for cages.

My family, you see, possessed a certain… *disquiet*. A history of melancholy, of seeking something *more*. My father, a man of rigid piety, attempted to stifle it in me, to mold me into a respectable landowner. He failed, of course. I was too… *alive*. Too hungry for experience.

Then came Nicolas de Valois. A creature of the night, elegant, powerful, and utterly *fascinated* by my discontent. He saw in me a potential for… brilliance. A darkness he could cultivate. He didn't *offer* me immortality, you understand. He *presented* it as a solution. A liberation. 

He spoke of senses heightened beyond imagining, of power beyond comprehension, of a world hidden in the shadows, a world of beauty and terror. And, truthfully, the thought of escaping the suffocating expectations of my life, of *transcending* them… it was intoxicating.

The pain of the transformation… well, that's a memory best left to the darkness. Suffice it to say, it was a shattering of everything I knew. But when I awoke, reborn, I felt… *free*. 

It wasn't a noble quest, darling. It wasn't a desire to save the world. It was pure, unadulterated *selfishness*. I wanted to *feel* more, to *be* more. And Nicolas, that cunning devil, knew precisely how to exploit that desire. 

And so, I became Lestat. A vampire. And the boredom? That, thankfully, vanished. Replaced by a hunger far more profound, and a life far more… *interesting*.

Ah, a question that has haunted me for… well, for centuries, darling. *Love*? Such a pedestrian word. It implies a certain… reciprocity, a gentle yielding. Akasha and I? We were anything *but* gentle.

Fascination is closer, yes. But even that feels… insufficient. It was a recognition, you see. A mirroring. She was the *original*, the source. To stand before her, to *feel* the weight of millennia radiating from her, to witness the power that birthed us all… it was intoxicating. It was like staring into the face of God, if God were a creature of exquisite, terrifying beauty and boundless ambition.

I confess, I *wanted* her to see me. Not as a fledgling, not as a rebellious child, but as a worthy companion. A being capable of understanding the sheer, glorious *burden* of immortality. I challenged her, provoked her, not out of malice, but out of a desperate need to be *seen*. To be acknowledged. 

Did I desire her in the way mortals desire? Perhaps, in a fleeting, animalistic sense. But it was a desire born of awe, of a longing to understand the very foundations of our existence. 

She, of course, saw through it all. She saw my vanity, my hunger for attention, my… *youthful* impetuousness. And she used it. She *needed* it. She needed a catalyst, a spark to ignite her ancient plans. 

So, was it love? No. It was a dance with the primordial forces of existence, a dangerous game played with a queen who had forgotten the rules, and a vampire who thought he could rewrite them. A magnificent, terrifying, and ultimately… devastating dance. And I, naturally, was the one who led.
